description:
This series of videos will provide you with the knowledge and skills to plan and administer a Microsoft SharePoint 2016 environment. You will learn how to deploy, administer, and troubleshoot your SharePoint environment. These videos also provide guidelines, best practices, and considerations that help you optimize your SharePoint deployment.

This is the first in a sequence of two courses for IT professionals and is aligned with the SharePoint 2016 IT Pro certification.
name: SharePoint 2016 - 70-339
subtitle: Planning and Administering SharePoint 2016

9

10

11

12

13

14

15

refinement and feedback,

16
00:00:44.070 --> 00:00:46.220

17

Is it perfect?

18
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:47.460
No.

19
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:48.650

20
00:00:48.650 --> 00:00:50.650
Yes.
It can mean many things to many people.

21

the ways where SharePoint can help you

22

your collaboration and so much more.

23
00:00:59.898 --> 00:01:03.730

24

in the episodes to come.

25
00:01:05.850 --> 00:01:06.400
>> Very good, Mark.

26
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:09.286

be talking from the ground up,

27

like somebody that's not familiar with
SharePoint, never used it before,

28
00:01:12.827 --> 00:01:14.248
is this a good course for them?

29
00:01:14.248 --> 00:01:18.285
>> Absolutely, with no assumed prior
SharePoint knowledge, a background,

30
00:01:18.285 --> 00:01:22.511
a general background in IT and working
with information is certainly useful but

31

we assume nothing.

32
00:01:23.596 --> 00:01:26.871
>> [LAUGH] And then for people that
are familiar with SharePoint but

33
00:01:26.871 --> 00:01:31.220
maybe are new to SharePoint 2016,
probably be a good fit for them as well.

34
00:01:31.220 --> 00:01:34.710
>> Absolutely, so what's in it for

35
00:01:34.710 --> 00:01:38.080
Microsoft has put a lot of

36

37

a lot in SharePoint Online.

38
00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:47.670
So we'll all be working in some kind
of hybrid environment eventually,

39
00:01:47.670 --> 00:01:50.230
if not a pure
SharePoint Online environment.

40
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:55.206
Of course, with that ties in with O 365,

41
00:01:55.206 --> 00:01:59.629
now it's time to jump on even in
a trial environment with Azure.

42
00:01:59.629 --> 00:02:01.823
It's definitely the future and
the future is now.

43
00:02:01.823 --> 00:02:02.867
So you wanna be ahead of the curve.

44
00:02:02.867 --> 00:02:08.235
So that's the reason for it, if you're an
experienced SharePoint administrator but

45
00:02:08.235 --> 00:02:11.922
do not yet use cloud services,
this course is also for you.

46
00:02:11.922 --> 00:02:12.770
>> Very good.

47
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:17.320
So, what kind of topics are we gonna cover
as we progress through these episodes.

48
00:02:17.320 --> 00:02:19.920
>> Well, we'll look at first
an introduction to SharePoint,

49
00:02:19.920 --> 00:02:21.260
some of the key functionality.

50
00:02:21.260 --> 00:02:23.520
Again, it can be many
things to many people.

51
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:26.890
We don't cover all
the technology of SharePoint.

52
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:28.735
We have an advanced class for that.

53
00:02:28.735 --> 00:02:29.330
>> [LAUGH].
>> However,

54
00:02:29.330 --> 00:02:33.410
you'll get a good grounding and then we'll
look at a lot of the success of your

55
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:37.070
SharePoint deployment actually has
nothing to do with touching the keyboard.

56
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:39.320
I'm talking about governance and planning.

57
00:02:39.320 --> 00:02:41.792
So the expression goes,
if you don't have time to plan,

58
00:02:41.792 --> 00:02:43.345
you have to make time to plan later.

59
00:02:43.345 --> 00:02:48.238
In other words, after you've screwed up,
plowed straight ahead without thinking,

60
00:02:48.238 --> 00:02:51.066
sort of the ready, fire,
aim approach, right?

61
00:02:51.066 --> 00:02:53.370
Or we'll fix it later, no.

62
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:56.060
So we really slow you down
in the beginning modules

63
00:02:56.060 --> 00:02:58.620
looking at things like
an information architecture.

64
00:02:58.620 --> 00:03:02.020
So if you do deploy SharePoint and
you're new to product,

65
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:04.540
it's a great time to look at
your existing information,

66
00:03:04.540 --> 00:03:09.460
how it's stored, often with mergers and
maybe moving physical locations.

67
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:13.992
A lot of literal and
figurative IT related junk goes with you.

68
00:03:13.992 --> 00:03:16.710
So maybe a good time to
prune out the old and

69
00:03:16.710 --> 00:03:20.130
also to standardize on classifications for
data.

70
00:03:20.130 --> 00:03:23.520
So that a customer for example,
in the sales department

71
00:03:23.520 --> 00:03:25.810
means the same thing as a customer
in the marketing department.

72
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:29.990
In terms of the data, how we describe
a customer, the data we retain etc.

73
00:03:29.990 --> 00:03:34.010
So, again governance is a key part of the
success of your SharePoint deployments.

74
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:37.030
We talk about design and
information architecture.

75
00:03:37.030 --> 00:03:41.780
And then we go into designing,
both logical and physical architectures.

76
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:43.910
So, how is information gonna flow?

77
00:03:43.910 --> 00:03:47.260
How many SharePoint service do
you need in your environment?

78
00:03:47.260 --> 00:03:48.560
Are you gonna go hybrid?

79
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:51.465
Are you gonna go with
the purely online environment?

80
00:03:51.465 --> 00:03:53.366
Lot of questions to ask.

81
00:03:53.366 --> 00:03:55.025
Office 365 integration?

82
00:03:55.025 --> 00:03:56.430
Are you gonna choose Yammer?

83
00:03:56.430 --> 00:03:59.390
Are you integrating SharePoint
with Exchange and Lync?

84
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:00.389
I know I've asked a lot of questions here.

85
00:04:00.389 --> 00:04:01.063
>> Wow, yeah.

86
00:04:01.063 --> 00:04:05.167
>> But these are some of the questions
we'll answer as you watch the episodes and

87
00:04:05.167 --> 00:04:07.331
watch the demos and our witty repartee.

88
00:04:07.331 --> 00:04:10.943
>> [LAUGH]
>> Some of the jokes are lame frankly,

89
00:04:10.943 --> 00:04:13.700
but you take it with the bad,
it's a mixed bag.

90
00:04:13.700 --> 00:04:17.510
So installing configuring the product,
we get into that.

91
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:20.922
Not at first, we get into that
later because again, we really want

92
00:04:20.922 --> 00:04:26.150
you to consider the governance aspects and
the planning first before installing.

93
00:04:26.150 --> 00:04:30.824
So, we'll look at farm settings, so
SharePoint farm is your entire SharePoint

94
00:04:30.824 --> 00:04:34.204
deployment, what settings have
to be made at that level.

95
00:04:34.204 --> 00:04:39.038
Provisioning of farm settings like
incoming email and outgoing email,

96
00:04:39.038 --> 00:04:41.821
integration with Office WebApp Server.

97
00:04:41.821 --> 00:04:44.422
And we show you how to
create web applications and

98
00:04:44.422 --> 00:04:46.550
site collections in SharePoint.

99
00:04:46.550 --> 00:04:50.500
So a way of allowing for
extending IIS websites to allow for

100
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:52.358
SharePoint functionality.

101
00:04:52.358 --> 00:04:54.610
And with it,
once we create site collections,

102
00:04:54.610 --> 00:04:58.318
then we can start creating other objects,
document libraries, sub-sites,

103
00:04:58.318 --> 00:05:02.530
et cetera, and really start using
SharePoint for what it's intended for.

104
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:04.620
We have a variety of service
applications as well,

105
00:05:04.620 --> 00:05:09.020
so we can provide services like search and
business connectivity services.

106
00:05:09.020 --> 00:05:11.550
So one of the great things about
SharePoint, we can connect to

107
00:05:11.550 --> 00:05:14.980
any organized data source and
bring it into a SharePoint environment.

108
00:05:14.980 --> 00:05:18.710
In other words, have it searchable
from within one interface.

109
00:05:18.710 --> 00:05:24.140
Some people deploy SharePoint, their prime
driver is search because the user is so

110
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:28.040
frazzled to having to go to multiple
data repositories with different search

111
00:05:28.040 --> 00:05:32.430
terminology and queries just to try and
extract data they need to do their job.

112
00:05:32.430 --> 00:05:36.759
So one of the topics we look at in this
course as well is that users often spend

113
00:05:36.759 --> 00:05:41.641
20 to 40% of their time throughout the
work week just looking for information,

114
00:05:41.641 --> 00:05:43.670
not even doing anything with it.

115
00:05:43.670 --> 00:05:47.280
Not synthesizing, prioritizing,
deleting, forwarding,

116
00:05:47.280 --> 00:05:50.800
creating reports, not just looking for
it and often they get frustrated and

117
00:05:50.800 --> 00:05:53.170
recreate it, a total waste of time.

118
00:05:53.170 --> 00:05:57.800
So by properly designing a search
interface in SharePoint, no matter where

119
00:05:57.800 --> 00:06:03.000
that data lives, inside your firewall,
competitors' websites, news sources,

120
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:07.693
government repositories, SQL databases,
Oracle databases, any organized data

121
00:06:07.693 --> 00:06:12.190
source can be indexed, searchable from
SharePoint and have the results displayed.

122
00:06:12.190 --> 00:06:14.606
Also the content from those external and

123
00:06:14.606 --> 00:06:18.952
internal data resources can be
displayed in a dashboard in SharePoint.

124
00:06:18.952 --> 00:06:22.774
So, that was Bill Gates' idea back
in the day in the 90's I believe,

125
00:06:22.774 --> 00:06:26.686
the digital dashboard, he got
credited with that, that terminology.

126
00:06:26.686 --> 00:06:31.219
So the idea of you get information feeding
into one screen rather then you having to

127
00:06:31.219 --> 00:06:32.940
go look at it, it comes to you.

128
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:37.365
And that could be things like KPIs,
stock reports, baseball scores.

129
00:06:37.365 --> 00:06:40.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Weather information,

130
00:06:40.350 --> 00:06:42.420
information on your commute time.

131
00:06:42.420 --> 00:06:46.671
Other KPIs like turnover,
year-to-date sales, whatever is important

132
00:06:46.671 --> 00:06:50.728
to you can come to you as opposed to
you having to manually go look for it.

133
00:06:50.728 --> 00:06:55.107
We'll talk, we'll have that information
displayed in a SharePoint context.

134
00:06:55.107 --> 00:06:58.995
We also, it can be very complicated if
you don't do it properly in terms of

135
00:06:58.995 --> 00:07:02.592
granting the right access to content
in a SharePoint environment.

136
00:07:02.592 --> 00:07:05.525
So, as always,
the law of least privilege applies.

137
00:07:05.525 --> 00:07:10.250
Give people just enough rights and
permissions to do the job, but no more.

138
00:07:10.250 --> 00:07:13.020
Sometimes people get lazy and
say we'll make that person a local admin,

139
00:07:13.020 --> 00:07:16.272
and then you hope they don't realize what
they can do with local admin privileges.

140
00:07:16.272 --> 00:07:17.045
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

141
00:07:17.045 --> 00:07:20.490
that's often the fault of the application
creator because they didn't

142
00:07:20.490 --> 00:07:23.930
configure the app properly so you have to
provide more permissions than possible.

143
00:07:23.930 --> 00:07:27.541
But in a SharePoint context, we'll
show you what permissions to apply and

144
00:07:27.541 --> 00:07:31.110
where inheritance kicks in, and
why you might wanna break inheritance?

145
00:07:32.550 --> 00:07:35.270
And we'll look at different
ways of authenticating as well.

146
00:07:35.270 --> 00:07:38.800
So not just internally in
our own organization but

147
00:07:38.800 --> 00:07:42.620
how can we provide a certain kind of
access to say partner organization so they

148
00:07:42.620 --> 00:07:47.350
can access certain documents or content on
our SharePoint site, without the hassle of

149
00:07:47.350 --> 00:07:50.650
us having to give them accounts in
our active directory environment.

150
00:07:50.650 --> 00:07:53.280
So you might have set up
federation services before for

151
00:07:53.280 --> 00:07:56.530
other kinds of collaboration between
organizations, a similar process here.

152
00:07:56.530 --> 00:08:01.040
We'll show you exactly what to do to
configure that partner authorization.

153
00:08:01.040 --> 00:08:03.460
And then also we'll get into
hardening the platform somewhat.

154
00:08:03.460 --> 00:08:07.140
Securing the platform so
farm level security, settings,

155
00:08:07.140 --> 00:08:09.720
changes to make in your
SQL server backend,

156
00:08:09.720 --> 00:08:15.090
to make hacking a little harder and make
your information a little more secure.

157
00:08:15.090 --> 00:08:19.780
Also we got total control over
the kinds of content people can save

158
00:08:19.780 --> 00:08:21.000
in a SharePoint context.

159
00:08:21.000 --> 00:08:24.330
We'll look at how to block certain file
types from living in your SharePoint

160
00:08:24.330 --> 00:08:24.850
environment.

161
00:08:25.970 --> 00:08:27.420
Taxonomy is a big part.

162
00:08:27.420 --> 00:08:29.270
This goes back to governance and planning.

163
00:08:29.270 --> 00:08:33.430
So taxonomy, a good example of
taxonomy is the duodecimal system.

164
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:38.180
It's robust, it stood the test of time for
a 100 years or more.

165
00:08:38.180 --> 00:08:41.896
So, no matter if you went to college
50 years ago or five years ago or

166
00:08:41.896 --> 00:08:45.525
five years in the future,
that duodecimal system still holds up.

167
00:08:45.525 --> 00:08:50.050
It still allows for
the classification of new knowledge and

168
00:08:50.050 --> 00:08:51.330
coexistence with old knowledge.

169
00:08:51.330 --> 00:08:54.198
So that is a kind of taxonomy, an example.

170
00:08:54.198 --> 00:09:01.770
Other taxonomy examples from the world of
species, fish, even plant life, rocks.

171
00:09:01.770 --> 00:09:06.490
I mean there's a schema or an organized
plan for how to classify that information.

172
00:09:06.490 --> 00:09:10.680
So, in a SharePoint context as it relates
to your organization, you need to have

173
00:09:10.680 --> 00:09:15.520
a way of classifying information
to make management of it easier.

174
00:09:15.520 --> 00:09:18.080
But also to make finding content or

175
00:09:18.080 --> 00:09:21.380
the findability of your
information that much easier.

176
00:09:21.380 --> 00:09:25.655
So we'll look at metadata, which is
involved in classifying and part of your

177
00:09:25.655 --> 00:09:31.580
taxonomy and why you probably want to
collect more metadata than you are now.

178
00:09:31.580 --> 00:09:35.625
We look at ways to automate that
collection process so that users aren't

179
00:09:35.625 --> 00:09:39.935
hassled with having to enter multiple
fields manually or pick from a list when

180
00:09:39.935 --> 00:09:44.146
they try and save a document in
a SharePoint document library for example.

181
00:09:44.146 --> 00:09:46.328
User profile is another
section of the course.

182
00:09:46.328 --> 00:09:50.687
This is great because we can import
content from active directory so

183
00:09:50.687 --> 00:09:55.000
information about individual users and
add to it big time.

184
00:09:55.000 --> 00:09:58.560
So we can surface more resources or

185
00:09:58.560 --> 00:10:01.230
more intellectual resources if you
like throughout our organization.

186
00:10:01.230 --> 00:10:06.990
So, it's said that 50 to 75% of what's
needed to run your organization comes,

187
00:10:06.990 --> 00:10:09.870
or lives in the minds of employees.

188
00:10:09.870 --> 00:10:13.630
In other words, it's not documented
anywhere, so that means I can't search for

189
00:10:13.630 --> 00:10:15.680
it easily until now.

190
00:10:15.680 --> 00:10:20.160
Because with SharePoint user profiles,
there are built in fields for

191
00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:25.140
things like alma mater,
hobbies, programming languages.

192
00:10:25.140 --> 00:10:29.710
Anything you want to expose like that that
there's no active directory field for,

193
00:10:29.710 --> 00:10:30.670
there is in SharePoint.

194
00:10:30.670 --> 00:10:32.570
We can also create custom fields as well.

195
00:10:32.570 --> 00:10:35.420
What this means is when I'm searching for
information, say,

196
00:10:35.420 --> 00:10:36.669
on a programming language.

197
00:10:37.770 --> 00:10:41.760
I dont just get some documentation,
I can find Fred Smith

198
00:10:41.760 --> 00:10:46.730
over in Anchorage is an expert in Python,
for example.

199
00:10:46.730 --> 00:10:48.244
Im gonna ping Fred right now,

200
00:10:48.244 --> 00:10:51.592
with presence awareness
I can see Fred's online.

201
00:10:51.592 --> 00:10:53.050
Im gonna ping him and ask him a question.

202
00:10:53.050 --> 00:10:56.214
Otherwise I would not necessarily have
known that Fred was a Python expert,

203
00:10:56.214 --> 00:10:59.850
especially if you have a large
geographically disbursed organization.

204
00:10:59.850 --> 00:11:01.660
So it can really make

205
00:11:02.950 --> 00:11:06.810
employees more resourceful to other
employees in the organization.

206
00:11:08.010 --> 00:11:08.940
Enterprise search.

207
00:11:08.940 --> 00:11:09.620
So as I mentioned,

208
00:11:09.620 --> 00:11:12.950
search is a big reason why people
deploy SharePoint in the first place.

209
00:11:12.950 --> 00:11:15.090
I'm not saying it's easy to setup,

210
00:11:15.090 --> 00:11:20.610
we'll show you some of the basics to set
up Enterprise search in your environment.

211
00:11:20.610 --> 00:11:25.560
That can be frankly a multi day process
and a thing,s something you tweak over

212
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:31.520
time to increase or improve the quality of
the results from various search queries.

213
00:11:31.520 --> 00:11:33.920
So I'm not gonna kid you here.

214
00:11:33.920 --> 00:11:37.560
It requires librarian type skills

215
00:11:37.560 --> 00:11:41.940
to be able to properly service
information from search results.

216
00:11:41.940 --> 00:11:45.430
And then we'd be remiss if we
didn't tell you how to monitor and

217
00:11:45.430 --> 00:11:47.110
maintain your SharePoint environment.

218
00:11:47.110 --> 00:11:51.830
So things like optimizing, caching,
we'll look at how to look at log files.

219
00:11:51.830 --> 00:11:53.740
Health analyzer rules.

220
00:11:53.740 --> 00:11:54.824
How to monitor network traffic?

221
00:11:54.824 --> 00:11:58.315
How to monitor, maybe a page loads slowly,
how to analyze that so

222
00:11:58.315 --> 00:12:02.199
you can identify elements of the page
that are causing it to load slowly?

223
00:12:02.199 --> 00:12:04.254
Often it's a poorly written web part.

224
00:12:04.254 --> 00:12:08.365
We'll look at how to secure your
environment that way as well in terms of

225
00:12:08.365 --> 00:12:09.118
web parts and

226
00:12:09.118 --> 00:12:14.700
content that users can access to maintain
the overall security of your environment.

227
00:12:14.700 --> 00:12:15.240
>> All right, Mark,

228
00:12:15.240 --> 00:12:19.120
sounds like we've got a lot of information
to go over that's gonna help me implement,

229
00:12:19.120 --> 00:12:22.900
deploy, work with, manage, and
maintain my SharePoint environment.

230
00:12:22.900 --> 00:12:25.890
There's also an exam associated
with this information, correct?

231
00:12:25.890 --> 00:12:26.590
>> Absolutely, Mike.

232
00:12:26.590 --> 00:12:30.430
It's the 70-339 exam from Microsoft,

233
00:12:30.430 --> 00:12:35.180
so we'll cover all
the objectives on the exam.

234
00:12:35.180 --> 00:12:38.500
Will you be able to pass the exam
after watching these episodes?

235
00:12:38.500 --> 00:12:39.042
Of course not.

236
00:12:39.042 --> 00:12:40.018
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

237
00:12:40.018 --> 00:12:41.950
>> You gotta get some hands on.

238
00:12:41.950 --> 00:12:46.820
And your day-to-day real world experience
with SharePoint will help tie you through.

239
00:12:46.820 --> 00:12:50.060
Gone are the days where you could just
read a book or watch some videos and

240
00:12:50.060 --> 00:12:52.290
just breeze in and
come out with a passing score.

241
00:12:52.290 --> 00:12:53.985
So I don't wanna get you
under any illusions.

242
00:12:53.985 --> 00:12:56.959
However, we'll cover all the concepts
that do appear on the exam.

243
00:12:56.959 --> 00:13:00.824
So you're not gonna be surprised
when you get hands on or

244
00:13:00.824 --> 00:13:04.700
when you attempt the exam at
the questions that come up.

245
00:13:04.700 --> 00:13:05.660
>> Very good Mark.

246
00:13:05.660 --> 00:13:08.960
All right, I'll tell you what, you've
got me excited about SharePoint 2016.

247
00:13:08.960 --> 00:13:11.852
I hope everybody out there
is as excited as I am.

248
00:13:11.852 --> 00:13:13.815
If you are, you are in the right place,
stay tuned.

249
00:13:13.815 --> 00:13:16.891
We got some really exciting
SharePoint episodes coming your way.

250
00:13:16.891 --> 00:13:25.959
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike talk about the structure and capabilities of a SharePoint 2016 environment. They also discuss the major changes for IT professionals in SharePoint 2016, including key components of a SharePoint deployment, new features in SharePoint 2016, and deployment options.
episodes.title: Introducing SharePoint 2016
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.167 --> 00:00:10.167
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.587 --> 00:00:16.067
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.067 --> 00:00:20.827
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
today we're going over SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.827 --> 00:00:24.985
And in this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at some of the new features and

5
00:00:24.985 --> 00:00:28.940
capabilities that SharePoint 2016
brings to us in the IT world.

6
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:31.020
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

7
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:32.070
How's it going Mark?

8
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:33.210
>> Going great, thanks Mike.

9
00:00:33.210 --> 00:00:34.500
Good to be here.

10
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:39.032
There's a lot that SharePoint can do and
we'll certainly have a lot of demos,

11
00:00:39.032 --> 00:00:42.687
some hands-on showing you some
of those nitty gritty things.

12
00:00:42.687 --> 00:00:45.133
One thing that's often overlooked though,

13
00:00:45.133 --> 00:00:47.907
are the planning aspects
of SharePoint 2016.

14
00:00:47.907 --> 00:00:49.962
Some of you may have had familiarity and

15
00:00:49.962 --> 00:00:54.790
experience with SharePoint all the way
back in 2001, the first major version.

16
00:00:54.790 --> 00:00:58.260
And we've moved on since then to 2003,
2007, 2010, 2013, so

17
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:03.320
this is the sixth major
release of SharePoint.

18
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:06.525
So, a lot of people say it
takes a vendor three cracks.

19
00:01:06.525 --> 00:01:09.455
>> [LAUGH]
>> To get it right with any release

20
00:01:09.455 --> 00:01:10.954
of new technology.

21
00:01:10.954 --> 00:01:13.494
So, for Microsoft,
you could argue that MOSS, or

22
00:01:13.494 --> 00:01:17.633
Microsoft Office SharePoint Server in
2007 was that third major release, and

23
00:01:17.633 --> 00:01:20.547
started getting real traction and
wide spread adoption.

24
00:01:20.547 --> 00:01:22.288
Some of the unhelpful,

25
00:01:22.288 --> 00:01:28.450
inflexible architecture designs you were
stuck with that you chose earlier on.

26
00:01:28.450 --> 00:01:31.493
But now we've got all
kinds of flexibility and

27
00:01:31.493 --> 00:01:34.546
the ability to alter at
any time our topology.

28
00:01:34.546 --> 00:01:39.975
So even those of you that have experience
with SharePoint might have skipped over.

29
00:01:39.975 --> 00:01:43.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because as IT pros and devs,

30
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:46.360
we tend to wanna get
right on to the hands-on.

31
00:01:46.360 --> 00:01:47.380
Just give me the splash screen.

32
00:01:47.380 --> 00:01:48.384
>> Get it installed,
let's play with it, let's do it.

33
00:01:48.384 --> 00:01:50.717
>> Yeah, yeah, installed.

34
00:01:50.717 --> 00:01:55.277
>> I think the saying here about if you
don't plan, you plan to fail, right?

35
00:01:55.277 --> 00:01:57.080
SharePoint being no exception.

36
00:01:57.080 --> 00:01:59.210
It can be a relatively
complex environment,

37
00:01:59.210 --> 00:02:00.490
depending on what you're setting up.

38
00:02:00.490 --> 00:02:04.590
>> Absolutely, so the way to guarantee
failure with your SharePoint deployment is

39
00:02:04.590 --> 00:02:09.355
to try and involve and install everything
that SharePoint can do at once.

40
00:02:09.355 --> 00:02:12.140
There's probably not a single
environment in the world

41
00:02:12.140 --> 00:02:14.960
that is using everything
that SharePoint can offer.

42
00:02:14.960 --> 00:02:18.690
So the way to succeed is,
first of all, know what you're doing.

43
00:02:18.690 --> 00:02:21.070
Why are you deploying
a SharePoint environment?

44
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:22.320
What can you expect from it?

45
00:02:22.320 --> 00:02:24.380
What is SharePoint not good at?

46
00:02:24.380 --> 00:02:26.080
And then take one at a time.

47
00:02:26.080 --> 00:02:31.560
So if you want to use it for a place
to collaborate on documents, great.

48
00:02:31.560 --> 00:02:35.220
Set up some team sites,
maybe an intranet portal.

49
00:02:35.220 --> 00:02:39.620
But don't go all out and move all your
data into SharePoint and then redesign all

50
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:43.180
your workflows at the same time and
do some auditing and compliance work.

51
00:02:43.180 --> 00:02:45.782
No, that's a guarantee for failure.

52
00:02:45.782 --> 00:02:48.062
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I've seen that happen.

53
00:02:48.062 --> 00:02:48.569
>> True.

54
00:02:48.569 --> 00:02:49.689
>> [CROSSTALK] been part
of that unfortunately.

55
00:02:49.689 --> 00:02:52.150
>> Yeah, so
we all have those horror stories.

56
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:53.980
It's uncomfortable at best.

57
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:57.360
So, the other thing with
SharePoint that is huge,

58
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:01.640
a huge part of the success
of it is end user training.

59
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:04.698
So you need to plan and
budget that in, why?

60
00:03:04.698 --> 00:03:05.792
Because users, well,

61
00:03:05.792 --> 00:03:08.867
human beings like doing things
the way they've always done them.

62
00:03:08.867 --> 00:03:12.793
So if you're telling them now, okay,
we don't want you to save new content into

63
00:03:12.793 --> 00:03:15.852
FileShare, no we want you to save
it to a document library, and

64
00:03:15.852 --> 00:03:20.080
there's some unlearning and relearning
to do, there's gonna be push back.

65
00:03:20.080 --> 00:03:24.328
If you've read Who Moved My Cheese?,
you'll know that we just resist change,

66
00:03:24.328 --> 00:03:28.707
even if intellectually we can obviously
see yeah, this is a better solution.

67
00:03:28.707 --> 00:03:31.078
Some people might say, well,
I'm only 18 years from retirement,

68
00:03:31.078 --> 00:03:32.275
I'm gonna keep doing it this way.

69
00:03:32.275 --> 00:03:34.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> Unless we force them to

70
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:34.990
use the new way.

71
00:03:34.990 --> 00:03:38.086
But the point is,
let's have empathy for end users and

72
00:03:38.086 --> 00:03:42.594
it doesn't have to be formal classroom
training, it could be video training,

73
00:03:42.594 --> 00:03:45.507
maybe you throw some
intranet video tutorials up.

74
00:03:45.507 --> 00:03:49.009
And then people can learn at their own
pace or just-in-time learning, but

75
00:03:49.009 --> 00:03:51.427
we're asking users to do
things in a different way.

76
00:03:51.427 --> 00:03:55.031
So, again, have some empathy, don't just
cut over and announce after the fact okay,

77
00:03:55.031 --> 00:03:58.150
this is the new way of doing things,
let people know well in advance.

78
00:03:58.150 --> 00:04:02.271
Maybe they can keep saving, for example,
to their files servers, familiar shares,

79
00:04:02.271 --> 00:04:03.348
up to a certain point.

80
00:04:03.348 --> 00:04:06.948
And then you say you know what,
it's read only, all new content,

81
00:04:06.948 --> 00:04:11.410
especially collaborative in nature,
must now be saved in a SharePoint context.

82
00:04:11.410 --> 00:04:15.650
>> I've seen that specific thing cause
failures in SharePoint deployments,

83
00:04:15.650 --> 00:04:19.290
where a company has invested lots of money
in deploying SharePoint, a lot of energy,

84
00:04:19.290 --> 00:04:20.550
a lot of resources.

85
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:22.635
But then don't follow up
with the training and

86
00:04:22.635 --> 00:04:25.424
the users end up not using it,
they stick with what they know.

87
00:04:25.424 --> 00:04:28.817
They try it, they think it's horrible,
they're like we don't like that.

88
00:04:28.817 --> 00:04:30.534
And they go back to what
they're used to and

89
00:04:30.534 --> 00:04:33.110
it's all because of a lack
of training there I think.

90
00:04:33.110 --> 00:04:34.600
>> Absolutely, Mike.

91
00:04:34.600 --> 00:04:37.800
And then people blame Microsoft or
they blame the expensive license.

92
00:04:37.800 --> 00:04:39.020
It didn't work for us.

93
00:04:39.020 --> 00:04:39.570
>> Yep.
>> So,

94
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:42.560
more than any other Microsoft
technology I've worked with,

95
00:04:42.560 --> 00:04:47.051
the failure to plan
appropriately with SharePoint,

96
00:04:47.051 --> 00:04:50.630
it's gonna be an expensive mess and
cause mass frustration.

97
00:04:50.630 --> 00:04:53.330
And it will be worse than
whatever you're using currently.

98
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:56.300
However, having said that, the reason
why SharePoint is my favorite Microsoft

99
00:04:56.300 --> 00:04:59.270
technology is it can do so many things.

100
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:00.000
Is it perfect?

101
00:05:00.000 --> 00:05:00.630
No.

102
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:03.920
Does it streamline workflow and

103
00:05:03.920 --> 00:05:07.480
eliminate duplication and allow for
all kinds of collaboration?

104
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:09.750
Yes, and
that's what we're gonna look at this week.

105
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:13.867
So SharePoint's been
called a Swiss Army knife,

106
00:05:13.867 --> 00:05:17.521
another way I like to describe
it is if you had or a metaphor.

107
00:05:17.521 --> 00:05:21.840
Let's say you had five blind people
trying to describe an elephant.

108
00:05:21.840 --> 00:05:23.310
Well, depending on where
they were on the elephant,

109
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:24.630
they'd have a completely
different experience.

110
00:05:24.630 --> 00:05:28.387
So someone might have a toenail,
trunk, ear.

111
00:05:28.387 --> 00:05:29.154
>> Right.

112
00:05:29.154 --> 00:05:32.170
>> And each person would swear,
this is how it is.

113
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:33.230
This is how the elephant is.

114
00:05:33.230 --> 00:05:35.257
And they'd be equally valid.

115
00:05:35.257 --> 00:05:36.837
But just a different perspective.

116
00:05:36.837 --> 00:05:40.991
So let's look at or talk about some
of the things that SharePoint can do.

117
00:05:40.991 --> 00:05:43.000
I mentioned document collaboration.

118
00:05:43.000 --> 00:05:46.350
So, for the typical user, they're okay.

119
00:05:46.350 --> 00:05:49.270
Or the way they've probably
been doing things is

120
00:05:49.270 --> 00:05:52.160
we'll just email an attachment back and
forth 20 times.

121
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:54.390
And the version numbers may or
may not be in sync.

122
00:05:54.390 --> 00:05:56.367
And who knows who made what change when.

123
00:05:56.367 --> 00:06:01.001
And it fills up the Exchange store, so
your Exchange admins are not pleased plus,

124
00:06:01.001 --> 00:06:05.145
again, without version control you
don't know who made what changes.

125
00:06:05.145 --> 00:06:10.460
So, you can have a document
library set up in SharePoint.

126
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:11.600
And it's one place.

127
00:06:12.730 --> 00:06:16.624
So I can go, for example, and
check out a document from the library.

128
00:06:16.624 --> 00:06:18.837
That means no one else can edit it,
only I can edit it.

129
00:06:18.837 --> 00:06:21.200
And then when I've done
my edits I can check in.

130
00:06:21.200 --> 00:06:24.610
Also, you can enable document
libraries for simultaneous editing.

131
00:06:24.610 --> 00:06:27.770
So, three of us can be working on
the same document, for example,

132
00:06:27.770 --> 00:06:32.680
at the very same time, and we could
each see the edits made by the others.

133
00:06:32.680 --> 00:06:34.680
But the point is, we have one version.

134
00:06:34.680 --> 00:06:39.350
We can keep multiple versions if we want,
but there's not multiple misnamed,

135
00:06:39.350 --> 00:06:41.610
or renamed versions
flying around the email.

136
00:06:41.610 --> 00:06:42.297
Very handy.

137
00:06:42.297 --> 00:06:43.260
>> Absolutely.

138
00:06:43.260 --> 00:06:49.427
>> So Bill Gates got credited with
this digital dashboard idea years ago.

139
00:06:49.427 --> 00:06:51.689
And the idea was let's get one screen, or

140
00:06:51.689 --> 00:06:56.750
wouldn't it be great to have one screen we
can go and have information coming to us.

141
00:06:56.750 --> 00:07:00.040
So a lot of companies now they have
information in different repositories.

142
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:03.580
So they might need different tools or
different kinds of

143
00:07:03.580 --> 00:07:07.660
queries to extract usable information
from those different repositories.

144
00:07:07.660 --> 00:07:10.990
So wouldn't it be great, again,
to have information coming in?

145
00:07:10.990 --> 00:07:15.150
So we have web parts
are a way of servicing or

146
00:07:15.150 --> 00:07:17.902
bring in data from other data,
any organized data source, so

147
00:07:17.902 --> 00:07:22.990
SQL databases, third party databases,
Weather Channel, stock ticker,

148
00:07:22.990 --> 00:07:27.430
baseball scores, whatever you want set
up in different places on your screen.

149
00:07:27.430 --> 00:07:30.517
Then you don't have to go search for
it, it comes to you.

150
00:07:30.517 --> 00:07:33.837
And this can be part of an intranet
home page, for example.

151
00:07:33.837 --> 00:07:37.077
So the same technology we can use for

152
00:07:37.077 --> 00:07:41.610
an intranet home page,
we can have team sites.

153
00:07:41.610 --> 00:07:44.060
We can have an extranet to
collaborate with partners.

154
00:07:44.060 --> 00:07:47.970
We can even make our Internet
site all hosted to SharePoint.

155
00:07:47.970 --> 00:07:51.880
So a lot of people now, they might have
a different solution for Internet,

156
00:07:51.880 --> 00:07:53.566
extranet, an intranet pages.

157
00:07:53.566 --> 00:07:55.923
Different tools, tough to manage.

158
00:07:55.923 --> 00:07:59.132
So by having a single source for
those pages,

159
00:07:59.132 --> 00:08:02.261
Much easier to manage
in terms of security.

160
00:08:02.261 --> 00:08:04.779
People need to allow access to
people outside our organization,

161
00:08:04.779 --> 00:08:06.850
since we are dealing with
such a connected world now.

162
00:08:06.850 --> 00:08:11.620
Collaborating suppliers, vendors
needing access to part of our network.

163
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:14.270
So again, a Swiss Army Knife,

164
00:08:14.270 --> 00:08:20.040
many things that you can do with
share point compliance is another

165
00:08:21.510 --> 00:08:25.530
useful functionality built into SharePoint
and the ability to audit access.

166
00:08:25.530 --> 00:08:28.800
We can use SharePoint as
a records management solution.

167
00:08:28.800 --> 00:08:33.890
Now is it as good as a pricier third
party records management solution?

168
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:35.860
No, is it 90% as good?

169
00:08:35.860 --> 00:08:37.320
Yes.
And for many companies

170
00:08:37.320 --> 00:08:38.870
that's all they need.

171
00:08:38.870 --> 00:08:41.940
So again it's not like you
can just install SharePoint.

172
00:08:41.940 --> 00:08:45.320
Just choose all the options and
voila, it's good to go.

173
00:08:45.320 --> 00:08:46.370
It requires planning.

174
00:08:46.370 --> 00:08:49.520
So that's why the information
architecture,

175
00:08:49.520 --> 00:08:54.130
which we'll get to as our next
major topic, is so important.

176
00:08:54.130 --> 00:08:59.150
Because what happens is, often people
will tend to okay, we got Sharepoint.

177
00:08:59.150 --> 00:09:02.390
Let's move all the content to SharePoint,
that's not necessary.

178
00:09:03.450 --> 00:09:06.450
Another reason people deploy SharePoint
is for the search architecture.

179
00:09:07.730 --> 00:09:11.590
So if all you did with
SharePoint was set up search

180
00:09:11.590 --> 00:09:16.050
which by the way is not a one and
done process either.

181
00:09:16.050 --> 00:09:20.160
It can take days, possibly weeks
to correctly configure search for

182
00:09:20.160 --> 00:09:20.760
your environment but

183
00:09:20.760 --> 00:09:25.200
the benefit is it doesn't matter what
data type you have or the data source.

184
00:09:25.200 --> 00:09:28.980
As long as it's some kind of organized
data source, or even a web page,

185
00:09:28.980 --> 00:09:34.740
file shares, internal websites, external
websites, any organized data source,

186
00:09:34.740 --> 00:09:39.910
you can crawl that content and
bring it in, index it in SharePoint.

187
00:09:39.910 --> 00:09:45.540
And it's one place users can go to search
for content no matter where it lives.

188
00:09:45.540 --> 00:09:46.320
>> Wow.

189
00:09:46.320 --> 00:09:51.110
So this is actually, we'll get to
information architecture later, but

190
00:09:51.110 --> 00:09:56.430
one of the benefits of search, if you
set it up properly, is it can overcome

191
00:09:56.430 --> 00:10:01.750
deficiencies or complete lack of planning
in terms of information architecture,

192
00:10:01.750 --> 00:10:06.940
especially a lot of companies, Mike,
that have been acquired or merged.

193
00:10:06.940 --> 00:10:09.710
And then you've got disparate
information architectures, and

194
00:10:09.710 --> 00:10:12.380
you kind of just throw them all together.

195
00:10:12.380 --> 00:10:19.070
Some people like to move, moving houses or
offices, and they take everything.

196
00:10:19.070 --> 00:10:20.765
Why, because well we might need it later.

197
00:10:20.765 --> 00:10:22.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or

198
00:10:22.050 --> 00:10:25.470
in an IT context,
we have this old file from 20 years ago.

199
00:10:25.470 --> 00:10:27.850
We don't even have the software
to open this file type anymore.

200
00:10:27.850 --> 00:10:28.810
But we might need it.

201
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:30.420
So let's take it with us.

202
00:10:30.420 --> 00:10:31.710

Now, there's reasons you may want
to separate out into tiers and

436
00:22:39.670 --> 00:22:43.230
have multiple servers and
we'll show you this later in the week.

437
00:22:43.230 --> 00:22:45.360
Multiple servers as part of
your SharePoint deployment, for

438
00:22:45.360 --> 00:22:47.650
example application servers.

439
00:22:47.650 --> 00:22:52.120
Web front end servers,this is what
the client machines connect into and

440
00:22:52.120 --> 00:22:54.830
then the web front end
servers relay requests.

441
00:22:54.830 --> 00:22:57.970
On behalf of the client machines to
the SQL server in the back end or

442
00:22:57.970 --> 00:23:01.850
the application server and
return results to those client machines.

443
00:23:01.850 --> 00:23:07.530
So as always, more is more,
you want redundancy at each tier

444
00:23:07.530 --> 00:23:12.790
if you can afford it and
that will give you better performance.

445
00:23:12.790 --> 00:23:13.930
Another neat thing that's new,

446
00:23:13.930 --> 00:23:17.710
because we're talking about what's
new in SharePoint 2016 here as well.

447
00:23:17.710 --> 00:23:21.840
Not just SharePoint in general,
is this concept of zero down time.

448
00:23:21.840 --> 00:23:25.650
So, if you think back to SQL Slammer Worm,
and

449
00:23:25.650 --> 00:23:28.230
the big reason why that wasn't deployed.

450
00:23:28.230 --> 00:23:30.770
Even months even after
a known patch was released,

451
00:23:30.770 --> 00:23:35.670
his companies were afraid or
reluctant to reboot their sequel servers.

452
00:23:35.670 --> 00:23:38.400
A, they weren't sure if they
were going to come back up and

453
00:23:38.400 --> 00:23:41.610
B, downtime would have cost them money.

454
00:23:41.610 --> 00:23:45.100
So now the idea is, since then by the way,

455
00:23:45.100 --> 00:23:48.320
Microsoft has made great strides and
done great work.

456
00:23:48.320 --> 00:23:51.140
In reducing the number of
activities that require a reboot.

457
00:23:51.140 --> 00:23:52.170
>> Yes they have.

458
00:23:52.170 --> 00:23:55.300
>> Sometimes you can even install
a service pack without rebooting,

459
00:23:55.300 --> 00:23:57.310
that really shocked me,
the first time I did that.

460
00:23:57.310 --> 00:24:00.430
Because of all the activities
you'd expect to require a reboot,

461
00:24:00.430 --> 00:24:02.600
service pack installation
would be one of those.

462
00:24:02.600 --> 00:24:05.210
But my point is now, and it's,

463
00:24:05.210 --> 00:24:10.460
if you have redundancy of the different
tiers, you can have zero downtime.

464
00:24:10.460 --> 00:24:13.760
Because they manage whatever
reboots are necessary to

465
00:24:13.760 --> 00:24:15.590
keep service availability high.

466
00:24:15.590 --> 00:24:18.590
And that's very important,
because if you've got a website and

467
00:24:18.590 --> 00:24:21.260
you're making sales,
millions of dollars a year.

468
00:24:21.260 --> 00:24:23.890
You can't afford to have a customer
show up at your website and

469
00:24:23.890 --> 00:24:24.750
get some kind of error.

470
00:24:24.750 --> 00:24:27.270
They will just go shop at a competitor or
at the very least,

471
00:24:27.270 --> 00:24:28.990
your reputation will be tarnished.

472
00:24:28.990 --> 00:24:33.080
Either they're growing too fast or they're
just clueless, people are impatient,

473
00:24:33.080 --> 00:24:35.380
they will just buy from the competitor.

474
00:24:35.380 --> 00:24:38.800
So zero downtime is a beautiful thing.

475
00:24:38.800 --> 00:24:40.370
>> All right, Mark,
A lot of great features and

476
00:24:40.370 --> 00:24:42.100
then there's still more new features,
right?

477
00:24:42.100 --> 00:24:43.200
That Javin told us about?

478
00:24:43.200 --> 00:24:43.800
>> Indeed.

479
00:24:43.800 --> 00:24:49.650
So Office Graph is one of my favorite
technologies, from that we have Delve.

480
00:24:49.650 --> 00:24:51.230
So what this does is,

481
00:24:51.230 --> 00:24:55.250
it looks at all the documents you've
worked on and your interactions.

482
00:24:55.250 --> 00:24:58.350
And it will service information
that it thinks is relevant to you.

483
00:24:58.350 --> 00:25:02.220
For example,
based on if it's your boss and

484
00:25:02.220 --> 00:25:03.980
it's a document you're
both collaborating on.

485
00:25:03.980 --> 00:25:06.740
That is an obvious indication that you're
going to want to see that prominently,

486
00:25:06.740 --> 00:25:08.060
if there has been a change made.

487
00:25:08.060 --> 00:25:12.160
So it looks at all your social
interactions, maybe your likes, or

488
00:25:12.160 --> 00:25:15.930
ratings, you might have
rated some content.

489
00:25:15.930 --> 00:25:18.960
And again, documents you've worked on and
uses some machine learning,

490
00:25:18.960 --> 00:25:22.190
as well,
to expose content that's relevant to you.

491
00:25:22.190 --> 00:25:25.550
Again, another way to,
rather than you looking for content,

492
00:25:25.550 --> 00:25:30.490
content comes to you and
keeps you in the loop.

493
00:25:30.490 --> 00:25:33.106
>> Skynet,
coming to us through SharePoint [LAUGH]

494
00:25:33.106 --> 00:25:33.640
>> [LAUGH]

495
00:25:33.640 --> 00:25:34.320
>> All right, Mark,

496
00:25:34.320 --> 00:25:36.430
well a lot of great information there,
we thank you for that.

497
00:25:36.430 --> 00:25:37.710
I know you've whetted our appetites,

498
00:25:37.710 --> 00:25:41.310
hopefully yours out there as well,
about aome of the capabilities.

499
00:25:41.310 --> 00:25:44.210
And things that we're going to be able
to accomplish with SharePoint and

500
00:25:44.210 --> 00:25:46.420
throughout the week,
we're gonna expand on those.

501
00:25:46.420 --> 00:25:49.920
Do some demos for you and
show you how to get this up and running.

502
00:25:49.920 --> 00:25:53.450
As well as, help you prepare for that exam
so that you can get SharePoint certifies.

503
00:25:53.450 --> 00:25:54.840
So we thank you for that, Mark.

504
00:25:54.840 --> 00:25:56.800
Everybody out there we
hope you enjoyed watching.

505
00:25:56.800 --> 00:25:58.060
Signing off for IT Pro TV.

506
00:25:58.060 --> 00:25:58.990
I'm Mike Roderick.

507
00:25:58.990 --> 00:26:00.600
>> And I'm Mark Ingram.

508
00:26:00.600 --> 00:26:02.472
>> And we'll see you next time.

509
00:26:02.472 --> 00:26:10.230

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike describe how to gather business requirements, and the key elements of a successful information architecture project. They also explain how to structure information within a SharePoint 2016 deployment and make it easy to find and retrieve.
episodes.title: Designing an Information Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.532 --> 00:00:16.138
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.138 --> 00:00:17.570
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.570 --> 00:00:19.882
Today we're doing our SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:19.882 --> 00:00:23.933
And specifically in this episode,
we're continuing our thought processes on

6
00:00:23.933 --> 00:00:27.810
designing our infrastructure, right,
planning to install SharePoint.

7
00:00:27.810 --> 00:00:30.320
Because we've already said that
it's a very important part.

8
00:00:30.320 --> 00:00:33.950
SharePoint's very complex, has a lot
of pieces and a lot of capabilities.

9
00:00:33.950 --> 00:00:38.718
And, odds are, your needs are not going
to include every single one of those.

10
00:00:38.718 --> 00:00:42.810
So we gotta think about what it is
we're gonna do with SharePoint, and

11
00:00:42.810 --> 00:00:47.270
how we're going to set it up to support
what we need to do with that information.

12
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:51.330
And so that means storing it within
SharePoint in a way we can find it.

13
00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:53.440
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

14
00:00:53.440 --> 00:00:54.560
How's it going, Mark?

15
00:00:54.560 --> 00:00:56.150
>> Good, Mike, thanks very much.

16
00:00:56.150 --> 00:00:59.010
Yeah, so
let's talk about information architecture.

17
00:00:59.010 --> 00:01:02.828
You'll find that there's two things that
make a huge difference with the success

18
00:01:02.828 --> 00:01:05.927
of your SharePoint deployment,
one is budgeting and planning for

19
00:01:05.927 --> 00:01:08.390
end user training, right in the get-go.

20
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:10.396
The other is planning successfully.

21
00:01:10.396 --> 00:01:13.342
If you don't plan, you plan to fail.

22
00:01:13.342 --> 00:01:17.240
So there's a lot of ad-hoc
environments out there,

23
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:18.610
in terms of information architecture.

24
00:01:18.610 --> 00:01:21.120
In other words,
no one's really thought it through.

25
00:01:21.120 --> 00:01:24.309
Or maybe if they have thought it through,
but there's a merger acquisition,

26
00:01:24.309 --> 00:01:25.385
sometimes more than one.

27
00:01:25.385 --> 00:01:29.420
And then you've got a hodgepodge of
disparate information architectures.

28
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:32.550
So, my purpose, for
the next few minutes is to

29
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.620
sell you on the idea of the importance
of information architecture.

30
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:41.960
So in the old days, we used to sell or

31
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:46.050
attempt to sell technology to businesses
just because we had the latest version.

32
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:46.616
>> Absolutely.

33
00:01:46.616 --> 00:01:49.100
>> There's no thought to it, I mean,
of course you should have it.

34
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:52.740
We just spent a year and a half creating
this new version, Mr. Customer.

35
00:01:52.740 --> 00:01:55.990
You should upgrade,
without regard to any kind of

36
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:59.230
business requirement that really would
make a difference to the customer.

37
00:01:59.230 --> 00:02:01.290
In other words, what's in it for them?

38
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:03.120
They wanna know, and
that's a reasonable question.

39
00:02:03.120 --> 00:02:06.660
So thankfully for years now we've been
much more on the side of business.

40
00:02:06.660 --> 00:02:08.710
Sure, pitch a technology, but

41
00:02:08.710 --> 00:02:13.300
only if there's a compelling business
reason that the customer should deploy it.

42
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:14.860
Don't just pitch it just
because you have it.

43
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:17.710
What problems are we solving?

44
00:02:17.710 --> 00:02:21.730
So, we need to understand
the business requirements.

45
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:23.930
Why are they using SharePoint?

46
00:02:23.930 --> 00:02:26.457
And remember, SharePoint can
do a lot of different things.

47
00:02:26.457 --> 00:02:31.110
But in almost every case, you're gonna
be dealing with manipulating, modifying,

48
00:02:31.110 --> 00:02:33.708
saving, storing, retrieving information.

49
00:02:33.708 --> 00:02:39.400
How can we categorize information
to make it easily findable?

50
00:02:39.400 --> 00:02:45.260
So studies have shown users can spend 10
to 40% or more of their time just looking

51
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:50.680
for information, like we talked about in
another episode, so, what a waste of time.

52
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:55.525
So what I'm saying is, if we spend the
time to properly classify our information,

53
00:02:55.525 --> 00:02:58.708
in other words,
set up an architecture, a taxonomy,

54
00:02:58.708 --> 00:03:00.944
we'll define that a little later on.

55
00:03:00.944 --> 00:03:05.270
If we spend that time up front,
we're gonna reap great benefits.

56
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:08.860
Users will be able to find the documents,
for example, they're looking for

57
00:03:08.860 --> 00:03:09.740
much easier.

58
00:03:11.290 --> 00:03:18.830
So we've got site columns and
content types and term sets we'll discuss.

59
00:03:18.830 --> 00:03:20.610
So what is a site column?

60
00:03:20.610 --> 00:03:25.000
A site column holds a piece of
information, a piece of metadata.

61
00:03:25.000 --> 00:03:26.980
Now, what do we mean by metadata?

62
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:31.335
Well, the best definition I know of is,
metadata is data about data.

63
00:03:31.335 --> 00:03:32.410
>> Yep.
[LAUGH]

64
00:03:32.410 --> 00:03:33.810
>> So let's say you've got a simple

65
00:03:33.810 --> 00:03:35.080
Word document.

66
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:37.720
Even if you only have one
letter in the Word document,

67
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:41.300
there's still gonna be a bunch of
metadata associated with that document.

68
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:44.890
For example, the author, the file size,

69
00:03:44.890 --> 00:03:49.310
the date the file was created,
the date the file was saved or modified.

70
00:03:49.310 --> 00:03:53.220
So it's information about the information.

71
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:56.640
Different file types will have different
metadata which makes sense to capture.

72
00:03:56.640 --> 00:04:00.730
For example, if it's a photo,
then focal length,

73
00:04:02.770 --> 00:04:07.010
resolution, file size
will all be relevant.

74
00:04:07.010 --> 00:04:08.880
So some metadata terms or

75
00:04:08.880 --> 00:04:13.098
site columns only make sense when
talking about certain file types.

76
00:04:13.098 --> 00:04:13.640
For example,

77
00:04:13.640 --> 00:04:18.190
there's no image size relating to
a Word document, doesn't make sense.

78
00:04:18.190 --> 00:04:22.100
So, depending on the file type and
depending on the business reason for

79
00:04:22.100 --> 00:04:25.380
the information,
we're gonna capture different metadata.

80
00:04:25.380 --> 00:04:31.280
So, SharePoint is one of those
technologies that to use properly,

81
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:33.500
you require governance.

82
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:37.476
So, a lot of what the success of
a SharePoint deployment comes in

83
00:04:37.476 --> 00:04:40.990
the planning stage, that's why we're
talking about it right up front.

84
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:43.820
It's very easy as a dev or

85
00:04:43.820 --> 00:04:47.930
an IT pro, even an end user,
people wanna get hands on right away.

86
00:04:47.930 --> 00:04:49.346
>> Yes.
>> Let's just get in there, and

87
00:04:49.346 --> 00:04:50.347
we'll figure it on the way.

88
00:04:50.347 --> 00:04:53.203
And if we screw something up,
we'll fix it later.

89
00:04:53.203 --> 00:04:54.968
>> I've had a boss like that.

90
00:04:54.968 --> 00:04:57.420
He was like, hey, we got this
new software, let's install it.

91
00:04:57.420 --> 00:05:02.020
No consideration as to what it might do
to anything else running on the network.

92
00:05:02.020 --> 00:05:03.107
>> Right.
>> Lack of planning.

93
00:05:03.107 --> 00:05:04.802
>> Install first, ask questions later.

94
00:05:04.802 --> 00:05:06.265
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not helpful.

95
00:05:06.265 --> 00:05:10.770
So today, in this episode we want to again

96
00:05:10.770 --> 00:05:15.910
enroll you in the idea of proper planning.

97
00:05:15.910 --> 00:05:19.015
That comes from governance, and
that comes from C-level buy-in, so

98
00:05:19.015 --> 00:05:20.681
you need a champion for this project.

99
00:05:20.681 --> 00:05:23.835
So in terms of information or
architecture,

100
00:05:23.835 --> 00:05:26.740
different divisions of a company, say,

101
00:05:26.740 --> 00:05:31.969
might define what seems like the same
term or entity, like a customer, for

102
00:05:31.969 --> 00:05:37.625
example, or a patient, people might think
the customer, how hard could it be?

103
00:05:37.625 --> 00:05:41.293
It's a customer, maybe we got their name,
their address, phone number,

104
00:05:41.293 --> 00:05:43.710
maybe the last time they
purchased something.

105
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:44.740
How hard could it be?

106
00:05:44.740 --> 00:05:48.030
Well the point is,
especially with mergers or for

107
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:53.020
finance, HR, sales, deployment,
different divisions

108
00:05:53.020 --> 00:05:56.260
are gonna have a different
interest in the exact same entity.

109
00:05:57.410 --> 00:06:01.340
For example, if I'm a research scientist
doing a study on patients, I might have

110
00:06:01.340 --> 00:06:07.810
a case ID or a research patient ID
number that only I'm interested in.

111
00:06:08.920 --> 00:06:14.470
But other kinds of information you want
to capture pertains organization wide.

112
00:06:14.470 --> 00:06:16.370
So my point is we need
to get people together.

113
00:06:16.370 --> 00:06:21.080
There was a Chinese chain,
a restaurant chain in the States and

114
00:06:21.080 --> 00:06:24.400
it was a franchise situation,
hundreds of stores.

115
00:06:24.400 --> 00:06:27.776
At one point the owner said, because
different people had different recipes for

116
00:06:27.776 --> 00:06:29.807
the exact same menu item,
he said you know what,

117
00:06:29.807 --> 00:06:32.061
we're gonna get these head
chefs together in a room.

118
00:06:32.061 --> 00:06:35.540
Nobody leaves until you've standardized
on these eight menu items.

119
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:38.068
What is kung pao chicken,
what goes into it?

120
00:06:38.068 --> 00:06:39.950
How big is the portion size?

121
00:06:39.950 --> 00:06:41.330
What sauces are we using?

122
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:46.100
That way when a customer goes
to an outlet in Florida,

123
00:06:46.100 --> 00:06:48.720
Georgia, Washington,
wherever, they're gonna get

124
00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:51.940
the same experience because we're
making the food the exact same way.

125
00:06:51.940 --> 00:06:56.482
That's the same principle when it
comes to defining metadata columns or

126
00:06:56.482 --> 00:07:00.100
site columns pertaining
to certain information.

127
00:07:00.100 --> 00:07:02.640
So, let's say with customer, we want,

128
00:07:02.640 --> 00:07:07.652
maybe we need their birth date and
physical location, so their address,

129
00:07:07.652 --> 00:07:11.660
maybe their shipping address, billing
address, and whatever else we need.

130
00:07:11.660 --> 00:07:15.356
So when I save,
let's say I get a new customer document,

131
00:07:15.356 --> 00:07:17.674
a new customer form, I fill it out.

132
00:07:17.674 --> 00:07:19.972
I save it to, let's say,

133
00:07:19.972 --> 00:07:25.280
a SharePoint library I have
to specify certain metadata.

134
00:07:25.280 --> 00:07:27.410
Now some of this could be
automatically specified.

135
00:07:27.410 --> 00:07:31.860
For example, the name of the person
saving the customer for the first time,

136
00:07:31.860 --> 00:07:35.050
the customer information, that would
be me, the currently logged in user.

137
00:07:35.050 --> 00:07:41.639
Maybe I have to attach also or associate a
particular salesperson with the customer.

138
00:07:43.140 --> 00:07:47.920
Or what region is the customer in, is it
north, south, east, west for example?

139
00:07:47.920 --> 00:07:50.010
So we can classify that customer.

140
00:07:50.010 --> 00:07:53.880
So, it gets managed appropriately,
that customer.

141
00:07:53.880 --> 00:07:58.533
So, some of the fields we enter
Maybe we can type them in, but

142
00:07:58.533 --> 00:08:04.290
it's better to choose from a restricted
list like a drop down menu.

143
00:08:04.290 --> 00:08:07.190
So when it comes time to
enter the metadata or

144
00:08:07.190 --> 00:08:12.720
enter the field of data for
region, they choose the drop down.

145
00:08:12.720 --> 00:08:16.490
They can only choose one,
and then it's standardized.

146
00:08:16.490 --> 00:08:20.510
Sometimes we see problems with
different abbreviations for

147
00:08:20.510 --> 00:08:23.380
states, for example,
especially if there's a merger involved.

148
00:08:23.380 --> 00:08:28.330
So you might call Florida FLA is
an abbreviation, I might call it FL.

149
00:08:28.330 --> 00:08:30.160
It refers to the same state.

150
00:08:30.160 --> 00:08:33.020
Cleaning up the data is
another conversation

151
00:08:33.020 --> 00:08:36.990
which we can do with some of Microsoft's
tools, but we'll leave that for now.

152
00:08:36.990 --> 00:08:41.140
But just know that I'm talking about
the importance of standardizing

153
00:08:41.140 --> 00:08:41.820
on definitions.

154
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:44.880
>> It's got to be an important part
of when you're dealing with so

155
00:08:44.880 --> 00:08:45.760
much information.

67
00:03:58.150 --> 00:04:02.950

All right, now down below, I'm just

00:06:04.430 --> 00:06:09.751

105
00:06:13.290 --> 00:06:16.920
So a site collection,

00:06:22.310 --> 00:06:24.970
we call it a content database.

108
00:06:24.970 --> 00:06:27.310
You can move site collections and

109
00:06:27.310 --> 00:06:31.220

like documents, for example.

00:06:31.220 --> 00:06:34.169

00:06:34.169 --> 00:06:38.480

00:06:49.760 --> 00:06:50.910
But at any given time,

116
00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:55.110

00:07:15.719 --> 00:07:20.348

00:07:20.348 --> 00:07:21.430
example.

00:07:21.430 --> 00:07:23.790

00:07:23.790 --> 00:07:25.660

00:07:25.660 --> 00:07:31.550

00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:33.890

00:07:42.210 --> 00:07:46.620

00:07:46.620 --> 00:07:51.626

00:07:51.626 --> 00:07:55.255

You don't necessarily wanna grant
them Active Directory permissions.

367
00:20:10.840 --> 00:20:14.260
And there's ways of setting up trusts
between different environments

368
00:20:14.260 --> 00:20:16.790
to allow those external partner or

369
00:20:16.790 --> 00:20:21.631
vendor organizations just enough access
to a part of your SharePoint environment.

370
00:20:22.940 --> 00:20:26.361
>> And last but not least,
we've got our company Internet site.

371
00:20:26.361 --> 00:20:29.741
>> Yeah, so often, you might
think that wow, anonymous access,

372
00:20:29.741 --> 00:20:31.000
how could that secure?

373
00:20:31.000 --> 00:20:35.200
But if it's a customer or Internet
facing site, that would be totally fine.

374
00:20:35.200 --> 00:20:37.780
You wouldn't expect just
someone perusing your products.

375
00:20:37.780 --> 00:20:38.651
They have to log in.

376
00:20:38.651 --> 00:20:41.147
In fact, it's totally annoying
when you go to websites, and

377
00:20:41.147 --> 00:20:42.640
they do require your details.

378
00:20:42.640 --> 00:20:45.449
They haven't given you anything yet
and they want something from you.

379
00:20:45.449 --> 00:20:47.388
It's like, well, I won't go there.

380
00:20:47.388 --> 00:20:50.565
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Anyway, so it's, so

381
00:20:50.565 --> 00:20:54.237
anonymous access can
be totally legitimate,

382
00:20:54.237 --> 00:20:59.520
a legitimate way of providing access
to a part of your deployment.

383
00:20:59.520 --> 00:21:02.780
And the great thing about SharePoint,
one of the great things, is you can have

384
00:21:02.780 --> 00:21:07.415
the same as opposed to other solutions
where you might have a separate vendor for

385
00:21:07.415 --> 00:21:11.870
your intranet compared to you externet,
and your Internet-facing sites.

386
00:21:11.870 --> 00:21:15.840
With SharePoint you can use the same
technology for all three of those

387
00:21:15.840 --> 00:21:21.320
applications, in terms of sites,
so that's very handy.

388
00:21:21.320 --> 00:21:27.040
And maybe there is a part of your Internet
site that does require log-in for

389
00:21:27.040 --> 00:21:27.720
deeper access.

390
00:21:27.720 --> 00:21:31.693
You know maybe some customer resources,
whereas if I'm a potential customer I get

391
00:21:31.693 --> 00:21:34.091
access to maybe some white
papers I can download.

392
00:21:34.091 --> 00:21:39.038
And there might be some deeper
resources available to customers only,

393
00:21:39.038 --> 00:21:44.080
in which case they can log in, or
just enter their user account details.

394
00:21:45.820 --> 00:21:49.330
>> So, really flexible in the different
ways that we can set it up, depending on

395
00:21:49.330 --> 00:21:53.900
what it is we're trying to accomplish, and
also very obvious that we can segregate.

396
00:21:53.900 --> 00:21:58.850
And we can make content available to
certain groups of people, certain teams,

397
00:21:58.850 --> 00:22:03.250
certain vendors without compromising
the security on our other resources.

398
00:22:03.250 --> 00:22:05.240
>> Right, and very flexible, too, Mike.

399
00:22:05.240 --> 00:22:07.130
So in the old days,

400
00:22:07.130 --> 00:22:12.280
as we mentioned, it was very
inflexible and rigid architecture.

401
00:22:12.280 --> 00:22:14.830
So you really had to know in
advance what you wanted for

402
00:22:14.830 --> 00:22:16.400
the life of your SharePoint deployment.

403
00:22:16.400 --> 00:22:18.940
And, it made sense to start from scratch,

404
00:22:18.940 --> 00:22:20.540
if you wanted to make any
architecture changes.

405
00:22:20.540 --> 00:22:23.580
Nowadays, we're well beyond that,
thankfully.

406
00:22:23.580 --> 00:22:24.930
So, it's very flexible.

407
00:22:24.930 --> 00:22:30.070
If you wanna provision a new web
application, create a new site collection,

408
00:22:30.070 --> 00:22:34.030
delete a site collection, total
flexibility, and that's a beautiful thing.

409
00:22:34.030 --> 00:22:36.516
We'll be showing a lot of those
settings as we go through the week.

410
00:22:36.516 --> 00:22:37.639
>> I remember that.

411
00:22:37.639 --> 00:22:40.950
I think I first started playing with
SharePoint back in 2003, I think it was.

412
00:22:40.950 --> 00:22:44.430
And it was that warning at
the very beginning of the install

413
00:22:44.430 --> 00:22:48.330
that really kinda got you a little
worried or intimidated, I guess,

414
00:22:48.330 --> 00:22:50.510
because it said,
you've gotta make this decision.

415
00:22:50.510 --> 00:22:53.940
Are you going to do a farm or are you
going to do a single server deployment?

416
00:22:53.940 --> 00:22:57.170
By the way,
you can't change this once you've done.

417
00:22:57.170 --> 00:23:00.050
And so, you're like, whoa, wait,
I don't wanna click anything just yet.

418
00:23:00.050 --> 00:23:02.580
So it did require a lot of
research ahead of time.

419
00:23:02.580 --> 00:23:05.490
So it's nice that they've given
us the ability to make changes

420
00:23:05.490 --> 00:23:08.350
if we start out with a single server and
we wanna move to a farm.

421
00:23:08.350 --> 00:23:10.010
It makes it easier for us to do that.

422
00:23:10.010 --> 00:23:11.640
>> Definitely, definitely.

423
00:23:11.640 --> 00:23:13.650
So that leaves us with
the physical architecture.

424
00:23:13.650 --> 00:23:15.920
So, everything we've
talked about is logical.

425
00:23:15.920 --> 00:23:18.110
Let's talk about some of the physical.

426
00:23:18.110 --> 00:23:20.440
And again,
this is one suggested way to go.

427
00:23:20.440 --> 00:23:23.930
It's certainly not the final
word in physical design, but

428
00:23:23.930 --> 00:23:26.440
it's a place to start.

429
00:23:26.440 --> 00:23:30.010
All right, so we can see here
a few sections of screen there.

430
00:23:30.010 --> 00:23:33.010
We've got a threat management gateway,
or firewall,

431
00:23:33.010 --> 00:23:37.210
right in the middle near the top, and on
the left-hand side, a perimeter network.

432
00:23:37.210 --> 00:23:40.280
So where vendors or
customers could access and

433
00:23:40.280 --> 00:23:43.492
inside the firewall our corporate
network over on the right.

434
00:23:43.492 --> 00:23:48.836
Notice that we have Active Directory and
DNS internally and a couple of SQL boxes.

435
00:23:48.836 --> 00:23:52.405
It's always good to mirror the SQL
back in if you have the budget for it.

436
00:23:52.405 --> 00:23:56.214
You need at least a separate SQL box,
when I say box,

437
00:23:56.214 --> 00:23:59.257
that could physical or virtual machine.

438
00:23:59.257 --> 00:24:02.088
Mirroring SQL back end is great for
performance reasons.

439
00:24:02.088 --> 00:24:07.680
You also wanna have high, at least gigabit
ethernet connections with low latency,

440
00:24:07.680 --> 00:24:10.260
less than a millisecond for
best performance.

441
00:24:10.260 --> 00:24:12.795
There's a lot of IO, there's a lot
of back and forthing between,

442
00:24:12.795 --> 00:24:16.070
cuz all the content in share point
is stored in the SQL back end.

443
00:24:16.070 --> 00:24:19.480
I mean there might be some file stream
references to video content say sort of

444
00:24:19.480 --> 00:24:24.460
the file system, but generally almost
all the contents in SQL, a lot of

445
00:24:24.460 --> 00:24:29.140
communication back and forth between
active directory, DNS and the SQL boxes.

446
00:24:29.140 --> 00:24:33.230
Open the perimeter network, okay so,
climb machines never interact

447
00:24:33.230 --> 00:24:36.810
directly with SQL in the back end or
even applications servers, no,

448
00:24:36.810 --> 00:24:40.690
climb machines always go through
a web front end server or WFE.

449
00:24:40.690 --> 00:24:45.240
It's good too, for performance, load
balancing, and high availability reasons

450
00:24:45.240 --> 00:24:50.100
to have at least two, preferably three or
more web front end servers.

451
00:24:50.100 --> 00:24:53.690
And because of the flex of architecture,
you can start small,

452
00:24:53.690 --> 00:24:56.060
add more functionality to your
SharePoint deployment and

453
00:24:56.060 --> 00:25:01.040
as expected demand increases then its
easy to provision additional roles.

454
00:25:01.040 --> 00:25:06.530
Especially nowadays, in the SharePoint
2016 environment where more improvements

455
00:25:06.530 --> 00:25:11.490
have happened, in terms of not having
to reboot your servers after patching.

456
00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:14.750
So, again, higher availability,
available to you.

457
00:25:14.750 --> 00:25:18.290
So, we've got, a variety of web
front end service here, for,

458
00:25:18.290 --> 00:25:21.650
you can see it in the upper left there,
Intranet.acme.com.

459
00:25:21.650 --> 00:25:25.570
And other web servers, or sorry,
web front end servers, for our Acme.com.

460
00:25:25.570 --> 00:25:31.932
So perhaps a customer
facing Internet presence.

461
00:25:31.932 --> 00:25:35.820
And that is all I've got to say on.

462
00:25:35.820 --> 00:25:38.620
Sorry, one more thing,
application servers.

463
00:25:38.620 --> 00:25:39.450
So.
>> Mm-hm.

464
00:25:39.450 --> 00:25:43.250
>> We can have a three tier environment
fact larger organizations will definitely

465
00:25:43.250 --> 00:25:44.810
probably start off with
a three tier environment,

466
00:25:44.810 --> 00:25:47.930
where you've got web front end
servers that interact with clients,

467
00:25:47.930 --> 00:25:51.600
take LAN request, serve back content and

468
00:25:51.600 --> 00:25:57.580
application servers can more specialize
to run a certain workloads and

469
00:25:57.580 --> 00:26:02.405
then in the back end, now we got our
SQL preferable mirror SQL databases.

470
00:26:02.405 --> 00:26:05.335
Now, you don't require
a dedicated SQL box.

471
00:26:05.335 --> 00:26:08.585
It could be an instance on
a SQL server that's mirrored.

472
00:26:08.585 --> 00:26:13.455
Although, if you can dedicate one or two
SQL boxes to your SharePoint deployment,

473
00:26:13.455 --> 00:26:15.325
that would definitely be preferred.

474
00:26:15.325 --> 00:26:17.705
Solid State Drives, again,
if you got the budget for

475
00:26:17.705 --> 00:26:20.420
it, huge increases in performance.

476
00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:24.260
Because we're measuring read or
write times in microseconds instead of

477
00:26:24.260 --> 00:26:27.630
milliseconds, nothing physical moving,
so that's the way we're going.

478
00:26:27.630 --> 00:26:33.220
Also, if you can't quite afford to go all
Solid State Drives for your workload,

479
00:26:33.220 --> 00:26:37.990
hybrid drives are a nice compromise where
you have some solid state storage and

480
00:26:37.990 --> 00:26:41.220
some traditional spinning physical disks.

481
00:26:41.220 --> 00:26:45.020
And with server 2012,
then now the server 2012 r2 in 2016.

482
00:26:45.020 --> 00:26:46.830
They're smart enough to prioritize and

483
00:26:46.830 --> 00:26:49.970
shift workload so
the most recently accessed or

484
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:54.350
most likely to be accessed content is kept
on the faster solid state storage, and

485
00:26:54.350 --> 00:26:59.590
the less frequently accessed content is
shunted to the slower physical drives.

486
00:26:59.590 --> 00:27:01.979
>> Yeah, I like those storage
tiers in our storage pools.

487
00:27:01.979 --> 00:27:03.200
That's fantastic.

488
00:27:03.200 --> 00:27:05.532
>> Yeah, indeed.
So, that's all I got.

489
00:27:05.532 --> 00:27:07.540
[LAUGH]
>> All right Mark, well I tell you what.

490
00:27:07.540 --> 00:27:09.220
It's again a lot of information, but

491
00:27:09.220 --> 00:27:12.610
a really good look at what
we've got going on as far as.

492
00:27:12.610 --> 00:27:15.080
Or what we can do I guess
is a better way to say it,

493
00:27:15.080 --> 00:27:16.350
with our SharePoint environment.

494
00:27:16.350 --> 00:27:20.760
Again a lot of planning goes into
successfully deploying SharePoint.

495
00:27:20.760 --> 00:27:22.670
You've gotta understand what
is it that I need to do?

496
00:27:22.670 --> 00:27:26.940
Am I just supporting internal users and
setting up my pages for

497
00:27:26.940 --> 00:27:31.340
them or my sites for them,
to share information among each other or

498
00:27:31.340 --> 00:27:34.760
am I setting this up so that we can
work with a partner organisation?

499
00:27:34.760 --> 00:27:38.470
Or do I have contractors that I
wanna make information available to?

500
00:27:38.470 --> 00:27:40.176
Do I wanna use it for my website,

501
00:27:40.176 --> 00:27:43.690
my actual public-facing website
that my customers visit?

502
00:27:43.690 --> 00:27:44.560
Or do I wanna do all of that?

503
00:27:44.560 --> 00:27:47.160
Right?
So, we really gotta plan out what it is

504
00:27:47.160 --> 00:27:49.790
we're gonna need to do,
because that's gonna change or

505
00:27:49.790 --> 00:27:55.010
impact our decisions that we make down
the road as we actually implement

506
00:27:55.010 --> 00:27:59.190
SharePoint 2016, which is what we're
getting ready to do pretty soon.

507
00:27:59.190 --> 00:28:00.930
So, we thank you for that Mark.

508
00:28:00.930 --> 00:28:03.880
A lot of great information there,
hopefully that helped you guys out and

509
00:28:03.880 --> 00:28:04.940
you enjoyed watching.

510
00:28:04.940 --> 00:28:08.160
But for now, signing out for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Roderick.

511
00:28:08.160 --> 00:28:08.780
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

512
00:28:08.780 --> 00:28:09.815
>> And we'll see you next time.

513
00:28:09.815 --> 00:28:18.660

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike describe the physical design requirements for SharePoint 2016, and the physical components necessary to fulfill the physical architecture design. They also describe how to map a logical architecture design to a physical architecture design.
episodes.title: Designing a Physical Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.063 --> 00:00:10.063
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.350 --> 00:00:15.252
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.252 --> 00:00:20.480
I'm your host Mike Roddick and today
we're going to be doing SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:25.028
And specifically in this episode, we're
continuing on with our planning phase and

5
00:00:25.028 --> 00:00:27.281
our deployment of SharePoint 2016.

6
00:00:27.281 --> 00:00:30.574
Now we're gonna take a look
at the physical architecture

00:00:30.574 --> 00:00:35.378
design considerations when we're talking
about the physical architecture of our

00:00:35.378 --> 00:00:37.100
SharePoint deployment.

9
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.810
And here to help us with that, of course,
is Mr. Mark Ingram, how's it going Mark?

10
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:43.250
>> Thanks, MIke, good to be back.

11
00:00:43.250 --> 00:00:47.750
Okay, so in the previous episode we
looked at some of the logical design

12
00:00:47.750 --> 00:00:53.350
considerations that you must address
before deploying SharePoint,

13
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:56.940
or before upgrading,
or pay the price later.

14
00:00:56.940 --> 00:01:02.530
Now, based on the results of

00:01:02.530 --> 00:01:05.930
discussions you've had and decisions

00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:10.690
that will naturally lead to, and

00:01:10.690 --> 00:01:13.370
So if it's just some

00:01:13.370 --> 00:01:17.430
then maybe you can install

19
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:18.770
When I say server,

00:01:18.770 --> 00:01:24.290
you can interchange physical server

21
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:28.820
Now in a production environment typically
you're going to have multiple servers

00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:32.890
depending on your budget for
licensing and hardware,

00:01:32.890 --> 00:01:37.150
there'll be some compelling reasons to
chose at least a two server design.

24
00:01:37.150 --> 00:01:42.380
So, at least a SharePoint server and
a SQL database in the backend.

25
00:01:42.380 --> 00:01:46.580
Typically in production though you're
going to mirror your back end, SQL box and

26
00:01:46.580 --> 00:01:51.780
probably have redundancy at every level so
your web front end servers,

27
00:01:51.780 --> 00:01:56.050
your application servers,
if any, more is more.

28
00:01:57.210 --> 00:02:00.690
In terms of specific hardware you're
going to look at, realistically,

29
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:04.240
at least 16 gigs of RAM,
24 would be better.

30
00:02:04.240 --> 00:02:09.170
Of course everything's 64 bit nowadays,
eight core wold be good,

31
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:12.230
again it depends if it's just
a test environment or production.

32
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:15.990
And if you forget or go cheap don't worry,
your users will remind you.

33
00:02:15.990 --> 00:02:17.080
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yes we will.

34
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:22.370
>> With helpdesk calls like this
page is taking 18 seconds to load.

35
00:02:22.370 --> 00:02:25.860
>> Yeah SharePoint does like
its resources doesn't it.

36
00:02:25.860 --> 00:02:29.900
>> It is a hog, [LAUGH] A beast,
if you will, you must feed the beast.

37
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:34.250
So depending on your architecture you
may be able to plug in more cores,

38
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:35.870
more RAM and that's good.

39
00:02:35.870 --> 00:02:39.900
So it's a good idea to plan for a year or
two out what you expect capacity to be.

40
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:43.440
So you may just be dipping your
toe in the water of SharePoint,

41
00:02:43.440 --> 00:02:47.940
trying some site collections if you're new
to product or even if you're upgrading,

42
00:02:47.940 --> 00:02:51.920
and we'll look at specific
upgrade considerations shortly.

43
00:02:51.920 --> 00:02:55.980
But even if you're upgrading, or new,
you're probably going to expand your

44
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:58.740
footprint of resources
SharePoint consumes.

45
00:02:58.740 --> 00:03:03.540
You might add on additional functionality
or turn that on or enable it by enabling

46
00:03:03.540 --> 00:03:07.287
features and setting up Record Center for
example, Enterprise Search Center,

47
00:03:07.287 --> 00:03:12.810
more intranet sites, maybe some line of
business software you're integrating or

48
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:15.960
accessing from SharePoint,
additional work flows, etc.

49
00:03:15.960 --> 00:03:17.835
So the point is, as word gets out,

50
00:03:17.835 --> 00:03:20.200
with your successful with
SharePoint deployment, and

51
00:03:20.200 --> 00:03:25.490
there's more demand to utilize SharePoint
for various work flows or processes,

52
00:03:25.490 --> 00:03:31.120
the demand is gonna go up on your RAM and
CPU usage.

53
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:35.260
So you want to, even if you're
not gonna start off with, say,

54
00:03:35.260 --> 00:03:38.950
24 gigs of RAM, maybe you're starting with
16, if you have available capacity, or

55
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:40.990
if you're running it all on
a virtualized environment,

56
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:44.800
if your host servers have available
capacity to upgrade, that's a good thing.

57
00:03:45.920 --> 00:03:50.280
What you don't want is to get bind from
your users to do various processes,

58
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:53.700
enjoy document collaboration for
example, search,
