00:03:53.700 --> 00:03:57.970
updating product lists, extranet,
collaborating with partners, and

60
00:03:57.970 --> 00:04:02.020
then find the performance
slowly degrading over time.

61
00:04:02.020 --> 00:04:03.840
That would be a bad thing.

62
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:07.170
You wanna always keep in mind that
you're in service of your users,

63
00:04:07.170 --> 00:04:09.620
whether they're internal and or External.

64
00:04:09.620 --> 00:04:13.700
So plan for what you expect capacity
to be a year or two down the road and

65
00:04:13.700 --> 00:04:16.650
you're probably underestimate it,
but you gotta start somewhere.

66
00:04:16.650 --> 00:04:20.100
Which brings up another point, in terms of
monitoring your physical infrastructure

67
00:04:20.100 --> 00:04:24.550
and how your software is running,
system center operations manager, or

68
00:04:24.550 --> 00:04:29.330
SCOM, used to be MOM, or Microsoft
operations manager, is a great tool.

69
00:04:29.330 --> 00:04:31.750
There are third party tools
you could use as well but

00:04:31.750 --> 00:04:37.110
rather than you having to
manually scour event logs and

71
00:04:37.110 --> 00:04:42.690
design your own counters and
maybe some alerts,

72
00:04:42.690 --> 00:04:46.520
wouldn't it be better to utilize the know
how of the SharePoint developers?

73
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:49.550
So, who better than them to know
what thresholds are important,

74
00:04:49.550 --> 00:04:53.115
what settings to monitor, what

00:18:04.810 --> 00:18:07.860
forms based authentication,
claims based authentication.

300
00:18:07.860 --> 00:18:12.250
Ideally you're not gonna, when you're
doing a migration you're not gonna create,

301
00:18:12.250 --> 00:18:14.180
that's a rather large project in itself.

302
00:18:14.180 --> 00:18:18.910
So keep the migration process or
upgrade process as clean as possible

303
00:18:18.910 --> 00:18:22.290
by not trying to do so
much at the very same time.

304
00:18:22.290 --> 00:18:26.180
>> We can do that, the authentication
migration after we've successfully

305
00:18:26.180 --> 00:18:27.410
migrated as SharePoint 2016.

306
00:18:27.410 --> 00:18:29.330
>> That's exactly right,

307
00:18:29.330 --> 00:18:33.440
that's a good idea to keep those
completely separate projects.

308
00:18:33.440 --> 00:18:37.170
Okay, so if you're running
an express version of SQL,

309
00:18:37.170 --> 00:18:39.400
that's no longer compatible
with SharePoint 2016.

310
00:18:39.400 --> 00:18:44.890
You'll need a full flavored
version of SQL 2014 SP1 or later.

311
00:18:44.890 --> 00:18:48.220
So SQL 2016 is okay.

312
00:18:48.220 --> 00:18:51.610
In terms of estimating your time for

313
00:18:51.610 --> 00:18:57.560
migration you should have some idea of
how big your site content databases are.

314
00:18:58.690 --> 00:19:00.410
That will help inform the time to move.

315
00:19:00.410 --> 00:19:03.450
And, again, the more you do it,
you'll get better at estimating

316
00:19:03.450 --> 00:19:06.350
the amount of time remaining to
migrate all the remaining content.

317
00:19:07.350 --> 00:19:13.180
Your hardware, you might again,
you want to verify after migrations.

318
00:19:13.180 --> 00:19:16.370
So, are the sites working
the way you expect them to?

319
00:19:18.740 --> 00:19:22.360
Fix whatever issues that exist
before migrating more content.

320
00:19:22.360 --> 00:19:24.110
And again, it's an iterative process.

321
00:19:24.110 --> 00:19:25.794
You get better as you go along.

322
00:19:30.739 --> 00:19:33.670
Another way to go is a scripted migration.

323
00:19:33.670 --> 00:19:37.570
The problem there is it might take
you a long time to hone the script

324
00:19:37.570 --> 00:19:38.250
to get it right.

325
00:19:38.250 --> 00:19:45.020
So, a third party solution is
definitely a good way to go, why?

326
00:19:45.020 --> 00:19:48.850
Because that third party developer
has had a lot of experience and

327
00:19:48.850 --> 00:19:53.580
experienced a lot of failure and
learned from glitches, or

328
00:19:53.580 --> 00:19:56.070
show stoppers,
that could prevent a successful migration.

329
00:19:56.070 --> 00:20:00.920
So, investing in a third
party tool is a good

330
00:20:00.920 --> 00:20:04.690
use of money to make that

331
00:20:04.690 --> 00:20:08.980
migration process much more seemless
than it otherwise would have been.

332
00:20:10.140 --> 00:20:13.090
>> Very good.
All right Mark again, just a ton of

333
00:20:13.090 --> 00:20:17.410
great information on planning out in
this case our physical architecture.

334
00:20:17.410 --> 00:20:21.200
If we go back to the previous episodes,
our logical architecture as well and

335
00:20:21.200 --> 00:20:22.750
just SharePoint in general.

336
00:20:22.750 --> 00:20:27.340
So a lot of important decisions to be
made before we ever touch the disk and

337
00:20:27.340 --> 00:20:30.890
start installing SharePoint if
we wanna be truly successful and

338
00:20:30.890 --> 00:20:32.140
have a good successful deployment.

339
00:20:32.140 --> 00:20:33.710
So we thank you for that Mark.

340
00:20:33.710 --> 00:20:36.920
Everybody out there we hope you enjoyed
watching as much as we've enjoyed

341
00:20:36.920 --> 00:20:38.170
shooting it for you.

342
00:20:38.170 --> 00:20:40.870
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

343
00:20:40.870 --> 00:20:41.512
>> And I'm Mark Ingram.

344
00:20:41.512 --> 00:20:44.020
>> And we'll see you next time.

345
00:20:44.020 --> 00:20:51.440
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike demonstrate installing SharePoint 2016. They go through the installation wizard, describing the different options available. Then they complete the initial farm configuration wizard to complete the installation process.
episodes.title: Installing SharePoint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.192 --> 00:00:10.192
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.646 --> 00:00:15.380
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:20.200
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:21.590
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:24.450
we're gonna look at getting
SharePoint installed, right?

6
00:00:24.450 --> 00:00:26.860
We spent a lot of time
in that planning phase.

7
00:00:26.860 --> 00:00:30.937
A very important part of a successful
deployment is making sure we know what it

8
00:00:30.937 --> 00:00:33.145
is we wanna accomplish with SharePoint.

9
00:00:33.145 --> 00:00:34.668
So we're installing what we need,

10
00:00:34.668 --> 00:00:37.320
not setting up what we don't need
because it is a big product.

11
00:00:37.320 --> 00:00:38.960
It can do a lot of different things.

12
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:40.909
So the planning phase was very important.

13
00:00:40.909 --> 00:00:44.900
But now we're ready to actually get it
installed and start implementing our plan.

14
00:00:44.900 --> 00:00:47.260
And here to help us with that of course,
is Mr. Mark Ingram.

15
00:00:47.260 --> 00:00:48.674
How's it going Mark?,
>> Thanks, Mike, great.

16
00:00:48.674 --> 00:00:51.745
Okay, at long last,
the moment we've all been waiting for.

17
00:00:51.745 --> 00:00:52.436
>> Yeah.

18
00:00:52.436 --> 00:00:53.833
>> Hands on the product.

19
00:00:53.833 --> 00:00:55.227
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's neat.

20
00:00:55.227 --> 00:01:00.270
So SharePoint is a three
gig DVD installation media.

21
00:01:00.270 --> 00:01:02.900
So I've got that queued up here.

22
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:05.740
And you'll see it in a box, very shortly.

23
00:01:05.740 --> 00:01:06.750
>> All right, we'll put that up.

24
00:01:06.750 --> 00:01:13.220
>> All right, so I'm in my DVD
drive there, and let's roll setup.

25
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:19.433
I wanna run as administrator.

26
00:01:19.433 --> 00:01:23.896
And there's, well,
actually a lot of waiting around.

27
00:01:23.896 --> 00:01:26.100
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

28
00:01:26.100 --> 00:01:28.230
>> We won't have as much today as you'll

29
00:01:28.230 --> 00:01:30.220
probably encounter out there in the wild.

30
00:01:30.220 --> 00:01:33.970
>> Yeah, this is one thing we've tried
to do is trim out some of the waiting

31
00:01:33.970 --> 00:01:35.740
process here for you guys.

32
00:01:35.740 --> 00:01:38.360
But it's definitely not
something you're gonna get done

33
00:01:38.360 --> 00:01:39.910
in an hour in the morning, right?

34
00:01:39.910 --> 00:01:40.566
>> True.

35
00:01:40.566 --> 00:01:44.307
As Gainesville's own Tom Petty said,
the waiting is the hardest part.

36
00:01:44.307 --> 00:01:45.054
>> That's right.

37
00:01:45.054 --> 00:01:47.110
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, so, here's a situation where,

38
00:01:47.110 --> 00:01:53.460
if you're starting a clean Server 2012
R2 installation, you need to make sure,

39
00:01:53.460 --> 00:01:58.820
there's actually several reboots
worth of Windows updates to install.

40
00:01:58.820 --> 00:02:03.300
And if you forget to reboot
after the last batch of updates,

41
00:02:03.300 --> 00:02:06.680
in this case for .NET Framework 4.6,

42
00:02:06.680 --> 00:02:12.680
then you'll be prompted that you
cannot continue and you must restart.

43
00:02:12.680 --> 00:02:14.480
I've now restarted.

44
00:02:14.480 --> 00:02:19.290
And the Product Key, there's 180 day
time bomb Product Key you can use for

45
00:02:19.290 --> 00:02:22.970
both Enterprise and Standard Editions,
different keys for each.

46
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:25.720
I'll enter the Enterprise Key.

47
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:28.089
>> So that way if you wanted to play
around with this in a test environment,

48
00:02:28.089 --> 00:02:29.403
you don't have to go buy it right away.

49
00:02:29.403 --> 00:02:29.932
You can just try it out first.

50
00:02:29.932 --> 00:02:33.442
>> Yeah, nobody should be forced to
plunk down $25,000 for a test drive.

51
00:02:33.442 --> 00:02:35.799
>> [LAUGH]
>> Your mileage may vary.

52
00:02:35.799 --> 00:02:40.283
Your expense may vary,
depending on your small business,

53
00:02:40.283 --> 00:02:43.480
woman owned, governmental NGO, etc.

54
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:47.110
So I tend to steer clear of actual
costs and licensing because there's so

55
00:02:47.110 --> 00:02:51.180
many deals I've encountered
over the years.

56
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:53.830
So File location,

57
00:02:53.830 --> 00:02:57.800
now it's always better to store
SharePoint content off the C drive.

58
00:02:57.800 --> 00:03:02.320
I mean you can move information off
the C drive, whether it's data files,

59
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:06.240
log files, search and
index files, that's better.

60
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:09.900
But in our test environment,
we're actually doing it all in one which

61
00:03:09.900 --> 00:03:12.068
is one of the modes you
can install SharePoint in,

62
00:03:12.068 --> 00:03:17.750
as we'll see those options after
this progress bar completes.

63
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:22.340
So you can have a multiserver deployment,
two server, single server.

64
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:25.867
Single server deployment would only make
sense in some kind of test environment.

65
00:03:25.867 --> 00:03:27.902
It's not certainly not recommended for
a production environment.

66
00:03:27.902 --> 00:03:30.782
>> And that's because performance
is just not gonna be adequate.

67
00:03:30.782 --> 00:03:31.518
>> Exactly.

68
00:03:31.518 --> 00:03:32.210
>> You try to do it on the same machine?

69
00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:32.736
>> Exactly.

70
00:03:32.736 --> 00:03:33.305
>> Okay.

71
00:03:33.305 --> 00:03:35.081
>> It's just asking one
machine to do too much.

72
00:03:35.081 --> 00:03:37.538
So when that finishes that section,

73
00:03:37.538 --> 00:03:43.100
then you can either run the configuration
wizard now, which we'll do, or later.

74
00:03:43.100 --> 00:03:46.140
Now you might say what's the point
of installing the binaries and

75
00:03:46.140 --> 00:03:47.450
then not actually configuring?

76
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:49.830
Well, maybe in a large organization,

77
00:03:49.830 --> 00:03:54.052
you don't have the privileges to run
the config wizard or vice versa.

78
00:03:54.052 --> 00:03:56.510
Maybe someone has to install it, and
you run the configuration wizard.

79
00:03:56.510 --> 00:04:01.530
Or maybe you don't have time that day,
so you can split up those tasks and

80
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:06.620
access the SharePoint's Product
Configuration Wizard as you can see now

81
00:04:06.620 --> 00:04:10.660
from the Start Menu,
if you have to resume installation or

82
00:04:10.660 --> 00:04:12.160
configuration at a later date.

83
00:04:12.160 --> 00:04:16.430
As usual, we have to stop and
restart services, IIS,

84
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:17.658
SharePoint Admitting Service.

85
00:04:17.658 --> 00:04:20.997
The SharePoint Timer Service
is a vital component and

86
00:04:20.997 --> 00:04:24.867
is involved in all kind of
processes relating to SharePoint.

87
00:04:24.867 --> 00:04:29.701
Some processes happen at every x number
of minutes, others are hourly, daily,

88
00:04:29.701 --> 00:04:31.274
weekly, monthly, etc.

89
00:04:31.274 --> 00:04:35.100
They're all get initiated by a timer job.

90
00:04:35.100 --> 00:04:40.710
So I'm either gonna join an existing
farm or create a brand new one.

91
00:04:40.710 --> 00:04:43.930
I've selected create a brand new
one which means I am creating a new

92
00:04:43.930 --> 00:04:45.490
configuration database.

93
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:49.440
In a real sense,
the configuration database is the farm.

94
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:54.490
So when you add additional servers to the
farm, you wanna make sure that you specify

95
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:59.280
joining an existing SharePoint deployment,
not creating a new one.

96
00:04:59.280 --> 00:05:01.530
Now, you need a valid domain account.

97
00:05:01.530 --> 00:05:06.420
So I showed you the dialogue box, if you
don't use a valid domain account, and

98
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:09.810
then using the correct one,
so it's domainname\username.

99
00:05:09.810 --> 00:05:15.600
And then a passphrase better than a
password, because a phrase can be a word.

100
00:05:15.600 --> 00:05:18.076
Maybe it's a slogan for some company.

101
00:05:18.076 --> 00:05:19.321
I'm loving it.

102
00:05:19.321 --> 00:05:21.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> For example, or

103
00:05:21.330 --> 00:05:23.070
something that's easy for you to remember.

104
00:05:23.070 --> 00:05:25.450
And you can have spaces in a passphrase.

105
00:05:25.450 --> 00:05:27.050
And I got another error there.

106
00:05:27.050 --> 00:05:31.865
Oops, I'm supposed to have some complexity
requirements, special characters,

107
00:05:31.865 --> 00:05:32.825
numbers, etc.

108
00:05:32.825 --> 00:05:35.844
So it's not as easy to guess.

109
00:05:35.844 --> 00:05:40.746
And you can change that passphrase later
if you want, but if you're joining

110
00:05:40.746 --> 00:05:45.810
new servers to your deployment later on,
you must specify the passphrase.

111
00:05:45.810 --> 00:05:48.630
Here's where I can choose,

112
00:05:48.630 --> 00:05:54.450
am I selecting a server to
join an existing deployment?

113
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:58.911
Or creating a brand new, in this case,
I'll choose single server farm.

114
00:05:58.911 --> 00:06:02.873
So again, not designed for production,
good for dev or testing, and

115
00:06:02.873 --> 00:06:06.035
when you want to just
explore the interface.

116
00:06:06.035 --> 00:06:11.100
I'm showing that you can select other

117
00:06:11.100 --> 00:06:14.850
server options, and then you get
a helpful description of the server role,

118
00:06:14.850 --> 00:06:19.350
in case you're not familiar with the
various roles in a SharePoint environment.

119
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:21.956
>> Now if we do a single server farm,
are we stuck with that?

120
00:06:21.956 --> 00:06:24.027
Or we can change that later on,
if we choose to?

121
00:06:24.027 --> 00:06:29.898
>> Yeah, we can't add to that later,
actually.

122
00:06:29.898 --> 00:06:30.722
We are stuck with that.

123
00:06:30.722 --> 00:06:31.631
>> Got you.

124
00:06:31.631 --> 00:06:32.440
>> Later in the week,

125
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:35.640
we'll look at a different environment
where we do have multiple servers.

126
00:06:35.640 --> 00:06:36.595
>> Okay, yeah.

127
00:06:36.595 --> 00:06:40.746
>> And now for the central admin site or
the web app rather,

128
00:06:40.746 --> 00:06:43.573
a bit of security through obscurity,

129
00:06:43.573 --> 00:06:49.598
we specify a five digit port number
up to 64K, so 1 to 65,000 in change.

130
00:06:49.598 --> 00:06:51.543
I just choose 55,555.

131
00:06:51.543 --> 00:06:55.370
Very few people should
have access to this site.

132
00:06:55.370 --> 00:06:58.720
Most people won't even
know about its existence.

133
00:06:58.720 --> 00:07:02.712
The reason is if you have access to that,
those farm little settings,

134
00:07:02.712 --> 00:07:04.412
you can do whatever you want.

135
00:07:04.412 --> 00:07:07.095
You can grant yourself
permissions to access or

136
00:07:07.095 --> 00:07:10.390
do anything you want in
an entire SharePoint deployment.

137
00:07:10.390 --> 00:07:14.327
So very should people should have
those farm admin permissions.

138
00:07:14.327 --> 00:07:19.310
All right, now this can take a while,
some steps rush by so

139
00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:24.445
fast, you might miss them,
others take their sweet time.

140
00:07:24.445 --> 00:07:26.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can see the various steps involved.

141
00:07:26.730 --> 00:07:29.729
Ten tasks which hasn't changed
from previous versions-

142
00:07:29.729 --> 00:07:30.905
>> All right.

143
00:07:30.905 --> 00:07:32.170
>> In the process of configuring.

144
00:07:32.170 --> 00:07:35.408
So we'll let this run.

145
00:07:35.408 --> 00:07:37.770
>> And
we got one of those famous progress bars.

146
00:07:37.770 --> 00:07:40.026
It really doesn't tell you
how far along you are,

147
00:07:40.026 --> 00:07:41.970
it just kind of scrolls across the screen.

148
00:07:41.970 --> 00:07:43.882
>> And
it could be hypnotic if you stare at it.

149
00:07:43.882 --> 00:07:44.730
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

150
00:07:44.730 --> 00:07:46.360
>> Do look away, periodically.

151
00:07:46.360 --> 00:07:49.318
>> We were talking about that
the other day, you and I, about,

152
00:07:49.318 --> 00:07:53.553
you had mentioned the stat about how users
spend 10 to 40% of their time looking for

153
00:07:53.553 --> 00:07:57.440
the stuff they need to do their job And we
were joking about how IT people probably

154
00:07:57.440 --> 00:08:00.470
spend ten to 40% of their time
staring at progress bars.

155
00:08:00.470 --> 00:08:01.580
>> That's right.
>> [LAUGH]

156
00:08:01.580 --> 00:08:02.170
>> That's right.

157
00:08:02.170 --> 00:08:03.840
Surely there's something else we can do.

158
00:08:03.840 --> 00:08:04.380
>> Right?
>> But

159
00:08:04.380 --> 00:08:07.830
no because often it requires babysitting
and you might go away for lunch and

160
00:08:07.830 --> 00:08:12.090
then realize the progress bar ended,
the task completed and

161
00:08:12.090 --> 00:08:15.750
it's waiting for some okay or
some one click to keep going.

162
00:08:15.750 --> 00:08:17.280
>> Yes.
>> Which is so frustrating.

163
00:08:17.280 --> 00:08:18.160
>> It can be annoying.

164
00:08:19.450 --> 00:08:20.400
For sure.

165
00:08:20.400 --> 00:08:24.508
All right so now we're on step ten,
finalizing the SharePoint configuration.

166
00:08:29.895 --> 00:08:33.430
Almost, wait for it.

167
00:08:34.710 --> 00:08:36.775
So exciting I can't stand it.

168
00:08:36.775 --> 00:08:41.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

169
00:08:41.900 --> 00:08:43.430
So I get this installed and then.

170
00:08:43.430 --> 00:08:46.710
>> Obviously we got a lot
more configuration to do.

171
00:08:46.710 --> 00:08:49.570
This is just basically
getting it installed.

172
00:08:49.570 --> 00:08:50.370
>> Absolutely.

173
00:08:50.370 --> 00:08:52.260
Okay, success.

174
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:53.430
Was there any doubt?

175
00:08:53.430 --> 00:08:54.080
No.
>> No.

176
00:08:54.080 --> 00:08:59.110
>> So you might want to screenshot this or
good to write down or

177
00:08:59.110 --> 00:09:03.050
somehow record you have the various
accounts they'll be using in a SharePoint

178
00:09:03.050 --> 00:09:05.560
deployment, as opposed to
trying to remember them all.

179
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:09.200
Keep in mind that you may not be
the only person configuring your farm,

180
00:09:09.200 --> 00:09:10.140
if you're a farm admin.

181
00:09:10.140 --> 00:09:13.620
So you should jot down those settings, and

182
00:09:13.620 --> 00:09:17.900
then when I finish that wizard,
let's see what happens next.

183
00:09:17.900 --> 00:09:21.620
You can see there,
if you look in the address bar.

184
00:09:21.620 --> 00:09:23.390
We've got the server name,

185
00:09:23.390 --> 00:09:27.530
which is SVR01 in this case,
with a colon and the port number.

186
00:09:27.530 --> 00:09:31.170
That's the five digit port number it
chose for the central admin website.

187
00:09:31.170 --> 00:09:33.740
So that's the way to navigate
there in the future.

188

a lot of content indexed,

00:01:33.387 --> 00:01:35.900

00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:41.424

00:01:41.424 --> 00:01:44.338

you just need to search once.

28
00:01:44.338 --> 00:01:47.701

a lot of changes get made to your content,

29
00:01:47.701 --> 00:01:51.929

that content get the most up-to-date data.

30
00:01:51.929 --> 00:01:56.754

contents more than twice a day,

31
00:01:56.754 --> 00:01:58.685
certain content sources.

32
00:01:58.685 --> 00:02:02.435

daily, even weekly,

00:02:02.435 --> 00:02:06.095

certain content types in your environment.

34
00:02:06.095 --> 00:02:09.095

it can add quite a heavy load.

35
00:02:09.095 --> 00:02:14.605
So, larger firms would have a separate
server just for crawling content.

36
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:18.000

00:02:18.000 --> 00:02:20.550

00:20:08.440 --> 00:20:12.120

Because that way it's more likely that

00:20:28.760 --> 00:20:33.460
users needing access for example to
resources hosted to site collection Or

00:20:33.460 --> 00:20:36.930
wanna be part of a group that accesses it.

00:20:36.930 --> 00:20:41.840
More likely to look at a response if two
people get emails rather than just one.

00:20:41.840 --> 00:20:44.680

I can create any number of
quota templates if I want.

00:20:53.380 --> 00:20:57.760

00:20:57.760 --> 00:20:59.070
or not use quotas at all.

00:21:00.230 --> 00:21:01.260
And here is a link here.

Unfortunately, if I were to

create another quota and then come

But no, I would lose this work so,

forget it I just gonna click okay and

Maybe a cycle actually

00:21:28.990 --> 00:21:29.610
>> Yeah.

00:21:29.610 --> 00:21:30.490
that's really good.

00:21:30.490 --> 00:21:34.240
>> At this point we're getting

00:21:35.300 --> 00:21:37.435
>> But the OK button has been depressed.

00:21:37.435 --> 00:21:40.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now don't be confused by this

00:21:40.430 --> 00:21:42.810
red text here saying no

00:21:43.890 --> 00:21:48.510
I fixed that, and I know I have fixed it

359
00:21:50.470 --> 00:21:54.850

kicks See whats going on there, and

00:21:54.850 --> 00:21:56.710

00:22:03.140 --> 00:22:08.310

00:22:08.310 --> 00:22:10.620
And we've got approximately one and

00:22:10.620 --> 00:22:14.710
a half gigabytes of REM allocated
to Sequel Server right now.

365
00:22:14.710 --> 00:22:18.200
So this just goes to show
how resource intensive.

366
00:22:18.200 --> 00:22:23.990
SharePoint is in terms of SQL impact,
that's why we preach the benefit of

367
00:22:23.990 --> 00:22:29.670
separate physical machine for SQL,
possibly mirrored SQL in the back end.

368
00:22:29.670 --> 00:22:32.880
Because there's a lot
of IO to the database,

369
00:22:32.880 --> 00:22:37.360
and it also underscores
the benefit of at least gigabit,

370
00:22:37.360 --> 00:22:39.930
preferably ten gigabit
ethernet in your environment.

371
00:22:41.300 --> 00:22:44.230
Yeah, especially, if you get, I know
we're doing it all on a single server for

372
00:22:44.230 --> 00:22:48.750
the demo, but you take two resource
intensive products like SharePoint and

373
00:22:48.750 --> 00:22:52.440
SQL, you put them on the same machine,
and you're bound to run into some issues.

374
00:22:52.440 --> 00:22:53.740
>> Indeed.

375
00:22:53.740 --> 00:22:54.616
>> Which we have.

376
00:22:54.616 --> 00:22:55.426
[LAUGH]
>> Ha!

377
00:22:55.426 --> 00:22:56.830
That's right.

378
00:22:56.830 --> 00:22:59.890
OK, this is interesting, because now it
says 'create new web application' but

379
00:22:59.890 --> 00:23:02.930
actually I'm creating
a new site collection.

380
00:23:02.930 --> 00:23:05.890
Although I did click on the link

381
00:23:05.890 --> 00:23:09.650
right on the end of the 'create
new application' dialogue box.

382
00:23:09.650 --> 00:23:12.000
>> So the wizard it still open
in the background somewhere.

383
00:23:13.100 --> 00:23:16.060
>> Yeah, I don't code the software!

00:23:16.060 --> 00:23:17.100
Nor does Mike!

385
00:23:17.100 --> 00:23:19.065
This is not the way I would do it.

386
00:23:19.065 --> 00:23:20.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> But anyway,

387
00:23:20.620 --> 00:23:23.930
we'll just wait for
that process to complete.

388
00:23:23.930 --> 00:23:29.080
Okay, excellent, so
yeah well actually in fairness the,

389
00:23:29.080 --> 00:23:32.470
the, new web app was still in

00:23:32.470 --> 00:23:37.130
We could Create a site collection
in the root of the web app at

391
00:23:37.130 --> 00:23:39.750

creation like we just did.

00:23:39.750 --> 00:23:42.960
Or I could have chosen to,
you know what I'm going for

00:23:42.960 --> 00:23:47.270
soda, I'll create the root
site collection later.

394
00:23:47.270 --> 00:23:52.306
So we did both there, and
then here's a helpful link.

395
00:23:52.306 --> 00:23:54.620
So I could click on that URL if I want.

396
00:23:54.620 --> 00:23:56.849
Let's do that just for a lark.

397
00:23:56.849 --> 00:24:00.137
See what happens, and as expected,
it's opening in another window.

398
00:24:00.137 --> 00:24:03.750
I'll come back to the original tab and
click OK.

399
00:24:03.750 --> 00:24:05.740
And then it should refresh and

400
00:24:05.740 --> 00:24:08.810
show our new web application in a list,
and it does.

401
00:24:08.810 --> 00:24:13.712
So that's right,
there's the SharePoint demo,

402
00:24:13.712 --> 00:24:17.360
and the URL path, and it's loading.

403
00:24:17.360 --> 00:24:20.550
It'll take a while, just like we
talked about in another episode,

404
00:24:20.550 --> 00:24:25.010
the importance of, if you have a site
collection that's likely to be visited,

405
00:24:25.010 --> 00:24:26.580
now it's asking for credentials.

406
00:24:26.580 --> 00:24:31.520
But, you'd wanna run a script to ping the,
or hit the site early in the day before

407
00:24:31.520 --> 00:24:34.270
your first employee comes, and
then when the first employee comes,

408
00:24:34.270 --> 00:24:37.390
that site is cached,
they don't have to wait a couple minutes.

409
00:24:37.390 --> 00:24:38.530
Now it's asking for credentials.

410
00:24:38.530 --> 00:24:41.010
Sometimes, you get annoyingly
repeatedly asked for

411
00:24:41.010 --> 00:24:43.440
credentials in a SharePoint environment.

412
00:24:43.440 --> 00:24:47.170
You should only get asked once, if at all.

413
00:24:47.170 --> 00:24:49.860
That depends on some internet
option settings you can tweak.

414
00:24:51.140 --> 00:24:52.300
All right.
So there is, again,

415
00:24:52.300 --> 00:24:57.150
back in my list of web applications.

416
00:24:57.150 --> 00:24:58.670
While we're waiting for
the other site to load.

417
00:24:58.670 --> 00:25:02.050
I can see it's still loading because
the circle is going around in the tab.

418
00:25:02.050 --> 00:25:04.080
Notice there's a delete option here.

419
00:25:04.080 --> 00:25:09.070
I can either delete the web app, and

420

associated with extending the web app.

421
00:25:13.690 --> 00:25:16.650
So a caveat here I've mentioned before,

422
00:25:16.650 --> 00:25:20.150
Whatever you can do in terms of
administration from central admin,

423
00:25:20.150 --> 00:25:21.030

424
00:25:21.030 --> 00:25:25.756
Don't think I am an IAS expert, I'll

00:25:25.756 --> 00:25:29.430
No, that's a bad move because then you
might come back to central admin site and

00:25:29.430 --> 00:25:31.750
make some changes that overwrite or

00:25:31.750 --> 00:25:36.285
maybe conflict with settings you
established by tweaking IAS setting.

428
00:25:36.285 --> 00:25:39.710
Some activities you must do in IAS,
like certificate settings for

429
00:25:39.710 --> 00:25:43.110
example, but
whatever you can do in SharePoint admin or

430
00:25:43.110 --> 00:25:47.720
via PowerShell, you should do it
that way and use IAS sparingly.

431
00:25:50.060 --> 00:25:52.970
Okay, so this is a good time to wrap up,
while we're waiting for

432
00:25:52.970 --> 00:25:55.220
this site collection to load.

settings in an upcoming episode.

00:25:59.750 --> 00:26:02.750
>> All right, so in all fairness,
we do sometimes give it a,

00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:07.650
It's creating the web application,

437

it's creating the site collection,
it's creating all the resources for that.

438
00:26:11.530 --> 00:26:15.210
It's creating the database and
SQL and all the entries.

439
00:26:15.210 --> 00:26:19.930
So we really shouldn't get too frustrated
or we need to be a little more patient,

440
00:26:19.930 --> 00:26:20.780
I don't know, sometimes.

00:26:20.780 --> 00:26:24.878
It seems like the faster computers get the
less patient I am with them sometimes, but

442
00:26:24.878 --> 00:26:25.810
a little patience.

00:26:38.130 --> 00:26:41.900

show you the results of the that creation.

00:26:41.900 --> 00:26:43.320

00:26:43.320 --> 00:26:44.071

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.128 --> 00:00:16.403
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here, at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.403 --> 00:00:17.770
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:20.923
Today we're doing SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:20.923 --> 00:00:22.397
And specifically, in this episode,

6
00:00:22.397 --> 00:00:25.300
we're gonna be taking a look at
configuring our site collections.

7
00:00:25.300 --> 00:00:26.220
In a previous episode,

8
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:31.050
we saw how to create our web application,
create our root site collection.

9
00:00:31.050 --> 00:00:33.460
Now we wanna go back and
make sure it's finished,

10
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:36.290
completed and
to configure that site collection.

11
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.816

So, since last we met, the site

collection has finished creating in the

Notice how Microsoft's been more

Invite more people to the site or

If you're on Windows 10, for example, and

00:01:23.072 --> 00:01:26.160
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, their blue screen has even gotten

>> Right that is a good point.

It a white screen.

00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:33.490
Okay.

31
00:01:33.490 --> 00:01:38.070
So, if you wondering about
the configuration of settings and

00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:42.180
options, keep in mind that
Microsoft is optimizing for Touch.

33
00:01:42.180 --> 00:01:44.920
Many of us are using hybrid machines.

34
00:01:44.920 --> 00:01:48.410
It's nice to have the space
between options so

00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:52.120

36
00:01:52.120 --> 00:01:55.650
Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

37
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:57.230
Lots to talk about.

38
00:01:57.230 --> 00:02:00.130
In the upper left corner, here,
we've got the S, I'm hovering over it,

00:02:00.130 --> 00:02:01.210
it says Demo Site.

40
00:02:01.210 --> 00:02:03.910
That is a good link to get back home,
in other words,

00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:08.450
to this very page from wherever
I may navigate in the site.

00:02:08.450 --> 00:02:11.310

with your company logo.

00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:17.140
Everything is replaceable,
even us, in your SharePoint site.

00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:22.298
I mean a site template is a suggested
arrangement, essentially,

00:02:22.298 --> 00:02:28.770
of how to configure in this case, a

00:02:28.770 --> 00:02:30.580

Home, and I click on Documents.

00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:38.010
It'll load up, and you can see, it says

I have a Site Contents link also,

So it will be a little a adjustment
to make the if you were working

00:02:52.630 --> 00:02:55.670
with SharePoint 2010 currently,
for example,

00:02:55.670 --> 00:02:59.480
then these icons may be a little
confusing, a little unfamiliar.

54
00:02:59.480 --> 00:03:01.136
I can add an app.

55
00:03:01.136 --> 00:03:01.769
I click on that.

56
00:03:05.389 --> 00:03:09.457
So I can add functionality,
like a Forms Library,

57
00:03:09.457 --> 00:03:15.430
maybe a little Announcement section,
a Discussion Board, Custom List.

58
00:03:15.430 --> 00:03:18.160
So it's good to peruse these options.

59
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:21.960
You are not gonna add all of them at once,
or on any given site.

60
00:03:21.960 --> 00:03:23.560
In fact, in your whole deployment,

00:03:23.560 --> 00:03:25.790
you might only use some of
the functionality of SharePoint.

62
00:03:25.790 --> 00:03:29.690
There's a survey, an issue tracking app.

63
00:03:29.690 --> 00:03:33.415
If I click on the arrow here,

00:03:33.415 --> 00:03:36.910
I can import a spreadsheet,

65
00:03:36.910 --> 00:03:41.820

that means it's optimized for

67
00:03:44.110 --> 00:03:47.590
It's not like we can not store

00:03:47.590 --> 00:03:50.540
It's just that the meta data columns,
and the site columns,

69
00:03:50.540 --> 00:03:54.870
the way we can classify data, are
optimized for a certain kind of content.

70
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:57.150
So if I went to a picture library,
for example,

71
00:03:57.150 --> 00:03:58.790
that would be optimized to store pictures.

72
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:03.380

length, the date picture was taken, etc.

73
00:04:03.380 --> 00:04:06.280
So just something to keep in mind there.

74
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:08.820
Now, I'll go back.

75
00:04:11.330 --> 00:04:13.820
The recycle bin we talked
about in another episode,

00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:16.330
how we have a two stage recycle bin now.

77
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:19.180
So I have a recycle bin at
a site I might create, and

78
00:04:19.180 --> 00:04:24.120
also my site collection administrator
has the second stage recycle bin.

79
00:04:24.120 --> 00:04:25.770
So that's a good thing.

80
00:04:25.770 --> 00:04:28.640
Now in case I forgot who I was,

81
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:31.450
I am actually the Site Collection Admin,
it says.

00:04:31.450 --> 00:04:32.540
Whoo!
>> [LAUGH]

00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:33.830
>> Which means I can see deleted

84
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:36.730
items from all sites in
this site collection,

85
00:04:36.730 --> 00:04:38.840
which could be potentially
thousands of sites.

86
00:04:38.840 --> 00:04:41.570
I can click a link there to learn more.

87
00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:44.562
And here's where I can
empty the Recycle Bin.

88
00:04:44.562 --> 00:04:47.880
If I can't find what I'm looking for,
there's a link, here, for the second stage

89
00:04:47.880 --> 00:04:52.070
recycle bin, which goes to the very
top level and, as it says here,

90
00:04:52.070 --> 00:04:56.000
I can see all items deleted from
anywhere in the site collection.

91
00:04:57.650 --> 00:05:01.150
First stage Recycle Bin in the default, is
to keep it in the recycle bin for 30 days.

92
00:05:01.150 --> 00:05:05.050
Beyond that, it goes to the site
collection Recycle Bin, and

93
00:05:05.050 --> 00:05:09.590
a maximum of 50% more than
the site collection quota

94
00:05:09.590 --> 00:05:14.080
worth of material will be saved
in the second stage Recycle Bin.

95
00:05:14.080 --> 00:05:18.210
If some new content hits the second stage
recycle bin which will push over quota, or

96
00:05:18.210 --> 00:05:23.610
over the 50% of the quota,
then the oldest item gets deleted.

97
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:27.340
Which means you're going to have to
restore from a back up if you want access

98
00:05:27.340 --> 00:05:29.220
to that content.

99
00:05:29.220 --> 00:05:29.730
All right.

100
00:05:29.730 --> 00:05:33.370
Now, there's an edit link as well.

101

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike discuss the Search service architecture, and how to configure the Search service in SharePoint. They demonstrate configuring Enterprise Search by configuring the Search service application and add a file share content source.
episodes.title: Configuring Enterprise Search
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.079 --> 00:00:14.841
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here it ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.841 --> 00:00:16.810
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:19.600
Today we're doing SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:20.790
And specifically, in this episode,

we're gonna be taking a look at

Microsoft Windows takes care

00:03:35.228 --> 00:03:37.348

00:03:37.348 --> 00:03:39.808
>> Yeah, that's good point,
that's a good point.

00:04:19.550 --> 00:04:22.568

00:04:30.828 --> 00:04:33.680

00:04:33.680 --> 00:04:35.000

00:05:26.442 --> 00:05:30.324

00:05:30.324 --> 00:05:32.170

00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:35.690
I kind of did that on purpose,

00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:43.590

For example, mistyping a user name or

00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:57.360

95
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:01.360
So kudos to Microsoft for

00:06:01.360 --> 00:06:04.990
It's really been a boon for
admins everywhere,

97
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:10.860
especially those of us who aren't devs and
don't have a lot of scripting background.

00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:13.990
They made it really intuitive,
often easy to learn and

00:06:13.990 --> 00:06:18.270
troubleshoot, and lots of built-in help
and online help as well for PowerShell.

100
00:06:18.270 --> 00:06:22.990
So I am an unabashed fan of PowerShell.

101
00:06:24.340 --> 00:06:26.415
This has been a sponsored announcement.

102
00:06:26.415 --> 00:06:27.548
>> [LAUGH]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike continue their look at SharePoint Online, focusing on the SharePoint Online admin center. 00:14:40.140 --> 00:14:40.846
>> Nice.
>> So, yeah,

261
00:14:40.846 --> 00:14:44.155
it just makes it a more
interesting experience for users.

262
00:14:44.155 --> 00:14:48.690
Now, a key consideration, again,
actually making the change in SharePoint,

263
00:14:48.690 --> 00:14:50.370
anyone can click a radial button.

264
00:14:50.370 --> 00:14:54.700
But knowing what the appropriate button to
click is, that's often a governance issue.

265
00:14:54.700 --> 00:14:57.300
This is one of those scenarios,
with external sharing.

266
00:14:57.300 --> 00:15:00.665
Are we gonna be kinda living in our
own walled garden, if you will,

267
00:15:00.665 --> 00:15:02.660
no sharing outside the organization?

268
00:15:02.660 --> 00:15:07.989
Or, are we gonna allow for external users
to access our content in SharePoint,

269
00:15:07.989 --> 00:15:11.261
but only if they sign in
as authenticated users?

270
00:15:11.261 --> 00:15:15.448
The other option is,
we're able to send sharing invitations to

271
00:15:15.448 --> 00:15:20.102
include external users, say,
participating in a document library so

272
00:15:20.102 --> 00:15:25.050
they can collaborate on documents there,
edit, check them out.

273
00:15:25.050 --> 00:15:29.240
And we can also have anonymous
access links with that option.

274
00:15:29.240 --> 00:15:31.630
In other words,
there's no sign in required.

275
00:15:31.630 --> 00:15:35.800
Just by virtue of having received an email
with a link to access a document library,

276
00:15:35.800 --> 00:15:37.510
for example, that is enough.

277
00:15:37.510 --> 00:15:39.230
There's no authentication to manage,

278
00:15:39.230 --> 00:15:41.920
there's none required from
the external user end.

279
00:15:41.920 --> 00:15:45.200
So that's certainly easier to
administer cuz there's nothing to do.

280
00:15:45.200 --> 00:15:47.734
So that default is to allow for
that behavior.

281
00:15:47.734 --> 00:15:51.187
As long as they e-mail you an invitation
to participate in the document library,

282
00:15:51.187 --> 00:15:53.500
you can participate without
having to authenticate.

283
00:15:53.500 --> 00:15:57.952
Okay, now there's always a consideration

284
00:15:57.952 --> 00:16:02.535
regarding old versions of site collection.

285
00:16:02.535 --> 00:16:06.660
So in SharePpoint 2013 On-Prem,
we had the ability for

286
00:16:06.660 --> 00:16:12.370
users to continue using the SharePoint
2010 version of their site collection and

287
00:16:12.370 --> 00:16:14.840
then upgrade at a time convenient for
them.

288
00:16:14.840 --> 00:16:20.160
We don't have that as much now in
a SharePoint online experience.

289
00:16:20.160 --> 00:16:24.710
With this default setting of prevent
creation of old version site

290
00:16:24.710 --> 00:16:28.070
collections but allow creation
of new version site collections.

291
00:16:29.390 --> 00:16:34.020
Opt in upgrade means people can,
if you pour it over to your content,

292
00:16:34.020 --> 00:16:37.200
say from on prem to the cloud,
it was created in SharePoint 2013,

293
00:16:37.200 --> 00:16:40.630
you can give the users
the option to Upgrade.

294
00:16:42.060 --> 00:16:45.060
So yeah, I'm definitely a fan of not

295
00:16:45.060 --> 00:16:48.630
allowing older versions of
SharePoint site collections.

296
00:16:48.630 --> 00:16:50.349
Let's move forward.

297
00:16:50.349 --> 00:16:53.097
It's much easier to support the current
version than to have to worry about

298
00:16:53.097 --> 00:16:55.509
customizations that might not
work with the previous versions.

299
00:16:55.509 --> 00:16:57.928
So sometimes, you have to drag people,
kicking and screaming.

300
00:16:57.928 --> 00:17:00.568
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or don't give them a choice.

301
00:17:00.568 --> 00:17:01.688
Or don't even let them
know there's a choice.

302
00:17:01.688 --> 00:17:02.268
>> Exactly.

303
00:17:02.268 --> 00:17:04.526
Surprise them.

304
00:17:04.526 --> 00:17:05.848
>> Surprise!

305
00:17:05.848 --> 00:17:08.538
So, there may be some slight
changes to functionality, but

306
00:17:08.538 --> 00:17:09.870
then they'll get used to it.

307
00:17:09.870 --> 00:17:12.460
There might be some griping, but
then they're in the new environment.

308
00:17:12.460 --> 00:17:13.218
Beautiful thing.

309
00:17:13.218 --> 00:17:14.638
Information rights management.

310
00:17:14.638 --> 00:17:19.158
Okay, this requires a rights
management services infrastructure.

311
00:17:19.158 --> 00:17:23.630
I love IRM because it gives
you additional layers of

312
00:17:23.630 --> 00:17:27.798
security beyond any
SharePoint permissions.

313
00:17:27.798 --> 00:17:32.370
On a per document basis or a document
library basis beyond what you're familiar

314
00:17:32.370 --> 00:17:34.730
with NTFS, or share permissions.

315
00:17:34.730 --> 00:17:38.730
So some further restrictions, as long
as I have the authoring capability for

316
00:17:38.730 --> 00:17:41.240
information rights management,
that means I can allow.

317
00:17:41.240 --> 00:17:45.800
Or a sign, particularly restrictions
to documents, for example.

318
00:17:45.800 --> 00:17:50.980
Do not print, which means if someone
tries to use the print screen command or

319
00:17:50.980 --> 00:17:54.550
Control C to copy any content,
that's not going to work.

320
00:17:54.550 --> 00:17:56.910
Another one,
restriction is do not forward.

321
00:17:56.910 --> 00:18:00.230
This is very useful if you have
internal use only communications.

322
00:18:00.230 --> 00:18:03.040
>> This should not go outside the
Firewall, if anyone tries to send it as

323
00:18:03.040 --> 00:18:07.120
an attachment or try to grant access
to somebody outside the organization.

324
00:18:07.120 --> 00:18:08.330
They'll be prevented from doing that.

325
00:18:10.160 --> 00:18:13.050
Let's see,
you can also expire content with IRM,

326
00:18:13.050 --> 00:18:16.660
this is very useful because, maybe
you've got time sensitive information.

327
00:18:16.660 --> 00:18:18.780
For example,
you're bidding on a construction project,

328
00:18:18.780 --> 00:18:21.260
maybe with three other firms for a bridge.

329
00:18:21.260 --> 00:18:23.840
The contest close date
let's say is July 15th, so

330
00:18:23.840 --> 00:18:27.680
on November 15th you're going to say,
that content expires.

331
00:18:27.680 --> 00:18:28.240
In other words,

332
00:18:28.240 --> 00:18:31.250
even if someone has a copy of it on
their computer the rights license,

333
00:18:31.250 --> 00:18:34.840
which is attached to the file, will expire
and the content will become unreadable.

334
00:18:34.840 --> 00:18:37.460
There are subscription models
like that with Apple Music and

335
00:18:37.460 --> 00:18:42.160
other vendors where you can you're good
to go as long as you pay the subscription

336
00:18:42.160 --> 00:18:45.490
as soon as you've stopped paying,
maybe 30 day grace period.

337
00:18:45.490 --> 00:18:47.528
All that information is unreadable.

338
00:18:47.528 --> 00:18:51.096
So information rights management
is a whole other conversation, but

339
00:18:51.096 --> 00:18:54.008
I just wanted to make you,
let you know it was available.

340
00:18:54.008 --> 00:18:58.019
And should users get to create a site?

341
00:18:59.870 --> 00:19:01.040
And where should they create it?

342
00:19:01.040 --> 00:19:06.350
So you can see this is pre-populated
here with HTTPS, so secure by default.

343
00:19:06.350 --> 00:19:09.450
There's my domain name
demoace.sharepoint.com/ and

344
00:19:09.450 --> 00:19:16.230
then that's where the new sites get
created, that part of the URL path.

345
00:19:16.230 --> 00:19:20.420
Now, I've said this before and I'll say it
again, if you want an environment where

346
00:19:20.420 --> 00:19:24.019
people have to make long form requests
in triplicate to get to be able to do

347
00:19:24.019 --> 00:19:28.091
something like create a new site, if you
want that kind of lockdown environment,

348
00:19:28.091 --> 00:19:30.768
SharePoint's probably not
the technology for you.

349
00:19:30.768 --> 00:19:31.414
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

350
00:19:31.414 --> 00:19:34.960
absolutely people should be
allowed to create their own sites.

351
00:19:34.960 --> 00:19:37.830
Or maybe they have to show that they've
gone to some one to learn session

352
00:19:37.830 --> 00:19:41.650
first and then they're given the keys
to be able to do that sort of thing.

353
00:19:41.650 --> 00:19:44.240
Now site classification,
in another episode,

354
00:19:44.240 --> 00:19:49.170
we'd be looking at content types,
site columns, so a way of organized, or

355
00:19:49.170 --> 00:19:53.790
applying meta-data to documents that's
about data in an organized fashion.

356
00:19:53.790 --> 00:19:56.430
>> Well,
another way to help users locate and

357
00:19:56.430 --> 00:20:02.160
class find information as they're created
is by requiring site classification.

358
00:20:02.160 --> 00:20:03.760
This means,

359
00:20:03.760 --> 00:20:09.060
if it's a required choice they have to
classify the site that they're creating.

360
00:20:09.060 --> 00:20:12.780
So that could be based on geography,

361
00:20:12.780 --> 00:20:18.110
division, departments,
maybe customer number.

362
00:20:18.110 --> 00:20:21.440
So anyway, I want to get you thinking,
as well, about different ways you can

363
00:20:21.440 --> 00:20:27.540
classify information to make
access to the content easier for

364
00:20:27.540 --> 00:20:31.280
users looking for it, and also a way to
manage the content in your environment.

365
00:20:31.280 --> 00:20:35.040
So this could be optional required
to classify the site, and

366
00:20:35.040 --> 00:20:39.400
that's whatever the user chooses when
they create the site collection.

367
00:20:39.400 --> 00:20:41.800
And then secondary contacts are useful.

368
00:20:41.800 --> 00:20:46.170
As I say, the primary site collection
administrator might be off on pat leave

369
00:20:46.170 --> 00:20:48.430
and then you need to get in
touch with that person for

370
00:20:48.430 --> 00:20:51.630
some reason, maybe someone's got
an access request, for example,

371
00:20:51.630 --> 00:20:53.260
they want to participate in that site.

372
00:20:53.260 --> 00:20:58.311
Having a secondary contact and
requiring one means that

373
00:20:58.311 --> 00:21:02.620
both primary and secondary site collection
administrators will get notifications or

374
00:21:02.620 --> 00:21:07.930
maybe there's a quota warning,
meet 75 percent of quota both admins

375
00:21:07.930 --> 00:21:13.030
should know so
they can take appropriate action.

376
00:21:13.030 --> 00:21:13.530
Okay.

377
00:21:14.890 --> 00:21:18.280
Now, do you want to allow,
with all the vulnerabilities out there.

378
00:21:18.280 --> 00:21:23.280
Crypto, scams, ransomware,
deleting content as everyday goes by.

379
00:21:24.640 --> 00:21:29.450
Scripting is often a culprit,
so you may want to prevent, and

380
00:21:29.450 --> 00:21:33.180
that's the default, prevent users from
running custom scripts pn personal sites.

381
00:21:33.180 --> 00:21:35.370
And you might say well it's a personal
site, what harm could be done?

382
00:21:35.370 --> 00:21:38.650
Well a lot of harm could be done,
so I like that that's the default.

383
00:21:38.650 --> 00:21:41.410
Now there may be a business reason to
allow for custom scripts, in which

384
00:21:41.410 --> 00:21:45.330
case you could choose "allow users to
run custom script on personal sites".

385
00:21:46.690 --> 00:21:48.255
There's a similar option for

386
00:21:48.255 --> 00:21:51.750
self-service created sites
that users might have created.

387
00:21:51.750 --> 00:21:56.420
And a helpful link ID there on the side
if you want more info on custom scripts.

388
00:21:57.790 --> 00:21:58.420
Okay.

389
00:22:00.140 --> 00:22:05.520
Now, depending on how cutting edge you
are and how cutting edge your users are,

390
00:22:05.520 --> 00:22:09.910
and how comfortable they are with
change you may want to enable or

391
00:22:09.910 --> 00:22:11.810
disable preview features.

392
00:22:11.810 --> 00:22:14.170
Preview features are.

393
00:22:14.170 --> 00:22:18.140
It's functionality that may or
may not be in the product full time.

394
00:22:18.140 --> 00:22:21.370
But Microsoft is experimenting,
in the wild.

395
00:22:21.370 --> 00:22:22.500
So you're a guinea pig.

396
00:22:22.500 --> 00:22:26.590
Just like Facebook, and LinkedIn, others,
will experiment with some functionality.

397
00:22:26.590 --> 00:22:28.290
They're not committing to keeping it.

398
00:22:29.380 --> 00:22:31.610
In fact, they probably,
sometimes don't announce that it's coming,

399
00:22:31.610 --> 00:22:32.280
it just shows up.

400
00:22:32.280 --> 00:22:34.325
And you say wait a minute,
I remember that button.

401
00:22:34.325 --> 00:22:35.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well that could be a preview feature,

402
00:22:35.970 --> 00:22:40.150
which may or may not be part
of the product going forward.

403
00:22:40.150 --> 00:22:44.770
So if that's sort of thing bothers you,
you don't like those kind of surprises,

404
00:22:44.770 --> 00:22:47.520
then you'd wanna disable preview features.

405
00:22:47.520 --> 00:22:52.160
And again, helpful link if you're
not sure about them, you can decide.

406
00:22:52.160 --> 00:22:57.930
Workflow, so workflows could definitely
introduce some kind of vulnerability.

407
00:22:57.930 --> 00:22:59.790
And as we've talked
about in other episodes,

408
00:22:59.790 --> 00:23:03.910
whatever you can dream up in an electronic
context, in terms of workflow,

409
00:23:03.910 --> 00:23:06.950
you can incorporate either on-prem or
online.

410
00:23:06.950 --> 00:23:09.880
So that could be the entire
onboarding process for example, for

411
00:23:09.880 --> 00:23:15.470
a new hire or creating contracts
with partner organizations.

412
00:23:15.470 --> 00:23:17.740
So, no matter how complex
you can imagine it,

413
00:23:17.740 --> 00:23:21.900
with database access,
multiple approvals at different levels.

414
00:23:21.900 --> 00:23:25.390
Calculated values or achieving databases.

415
00:23:25.390 --> 00:23:28.100
Very complex workflows,
whatever you can dream up you can do.

416
00:23:28.100 --> 00:23:32.409
You may wanna block
SharePoint 2013 workflows,

417
00:23:32.409 --> 00:23:37.195
maybe you don't wanna use any
workflows at all early on your

418
00:23:37.195 --> 00:23:41.418
SharePoint online journey,
and then access apps.

419
00:23:41.418 --> 00:23:44.158
So Access is a junior sequel
database if you like.

420
00:23:44.158 --> 00:23:49.225
You may want to enable or
disable that functionality,

421
00:23:49.225 --> 00:23:53.558
or the ability to access apps-
>> [LAUGH].

422
00:23:53.558 --> 00:23:55.158
>> if you will.

423
00:23:55.158 --> 00:23:58.030
Okay.

424
00:23:58.030 --> 00:24:01.370
Actually, one more thing here,
let's go to configure hybrid.

425
00:24:03.390 --> 00:24:07.970
So we could have hybrid One Drive and
sites feature.

426
00:24:07.970 --> 00:24:11.210
So, these both involve re-direction.

427
00:24:11.210 --> 00:24:15.180
The best way to describe that is,
for example, when users save

428
00:24:15.180 --> 00:24:19.970
something to their my documents folder,
even their desktop on-prem.

429
00:24:19.970 --> 00:24:22.250
You might of set up redirection
through your policy so

430
00:24:22.250 --> 00:24:25.420
that it actually gets
saved on your file server.

431
00:24:25.420 --> 00:24:30.030
The user doesn't know or necessarily care,
the benefit is to us as IT admins is

432
00:24:30.030 --> 00:24:32.930
we can have a centralized place
to backup important content.

433
00:24:32.930 --> 00:24:38.660
Similar idea with Hybrid OneDrive and
sites, there's redirection involved so

434
00:24:38.660 --> 00:24:44.190
that we can centralize the one
drive material and sites online.

435
00:24:48.120 --> 00:24:50.660
>> Alright, Marco again a lot
of great information there,

436
00:24:50.660 --> 00:24:54.200
a really great look at
SharePoint online and

437
00:24:54.200 --> 00:24:57.310
what we can expect if we need to manage
that SharePoint online environment.

438
00:24:57.310 --> 00:24:59.600
So we thank you for that,
appreciate those great Demos.

439
00:24:59.600 --> 00:25:02.130
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

440
00:25:02.130 --> 00:25:04.788
Signing of for ITProTV, I'm Mike Roderick.

441
00:25:04.788 --> 00:25:05.628
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

442
00:25:05.628 --> 00:25:08.168
>> And we'll see you next time.

443

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike discuss configuring SharePoint Online search capabilities. They look at how to optimize search results by defining indexed fields, and promoting sites. They also look at creating search suggestions and managing result sources and query rules.
episodes.title: SharePoint Online Search Administration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.030 --> 00:00:10.030
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.011 --> 00:00:12.545
Hello.

3
00:00:12.545 --> 00:00:17.297
Welcome to another exciting episode here
on ITProTV I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

4
00:00:17.297 --> 00:00:22.049
today we're doing SharePoint 2016, and
specifically in this episode, we're

5
00:00:22.049 --> 00:00:26.680
gonna be taking a look at configuring our
SharePoint online search capabilities.

6
00:00:26.680 --> 00:00:31.150
We've all ready talked about how really
fantastic SharePoint is about being able

7
00:00:31.150 --> 00:00:35.160
to search across all of our
different data sources and

8
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:39.950
data stores, we got that same
capability up in SharePoint online.

9
00:00:39.950 --> 00:00:42.740
So here to help us get that set up is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:43.630
How's it going, Mark?

11
00:00:43.630 --> 00:00:45.062
>> Hey, Mike.
Thanks very much.

12
00:00:45.062 --> 00:00:45.910
All right,

13
00:00:45.910 --> 00:00:50.910
let's look at the search admin interface
in our SharePoint online environment.

14
00:00:50.910 --> 00:00:55.700
So first thing we're going to
look at is our search schema.

15
00:00:55.700 --> 00:00:56.700
What is a schema?

16
00:00:56.700 --> 00:01:01.320
We come across this in exchange,
for example, active directory.

17
00:01:01.320 --> 00:01:03.200
Think of it as a skeleton or framework.

18
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:08.340
Click on that one and

19
00:01:08.340 --> 00:01:15.130
these show all the properties that
are searchable, therefore queriable.

20
00:01:15.130 --> 00:01:16.110
Now.

21
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:19.500
You may not need to crawl
all these properties.

22
00:01:19.500 --> 00:01:23.390
In other words, glean or
gather information during a crawl process,

23
00:01:23.390 --> 00:01:27.240
where we're pulling information
into an index, it gets indexed and

24
00:01:27.240 --> 00:01:30.620
then we can search based on
those fields or properties.

25
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:34.860
So, you may have no need for
some of these properties,

26
00:01:34.860 --> 00:01:37.760
in which case you can disable them or
turn them off so those properties won't

27
00:01:37.760 --> 00:01:41.240
be crawled in the first place, if they
exist in the crawled content sources.

28
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:44.740
>> Will that help us performance wise if
we just disable some of those unnecessary

29
00:01:44.740 --> 00:01:45.670
search terms?

30
00:01:45.670 --> 00:01:47.480
>> Absolutely, well specifically indexing.

31
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:50.600
So if the content of the metadata
is not indexed in the first place,

32
00:01:50.600 --> 00:01:56.320
its gonna be faster and make for more
efficient index and then a faster career

33
00:01:56.320 --> 00:02:03.070
results as well when it does come time
to play and actually execute a search.

34
00:02:03.070 --> 00:02:06.526
Now, having said that you may have custom
fields that do need to be indexed.

35
00:02:06.526 --> 00:02:12.420
So, you may have for example a rank or
a serial number, any kind of custom

36
00:02:12.420 --> 00:02:18.260
field that you want that property
Index and therefore searchable.

37
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:23.520
So, look at some of what exists here,
things like content type

38
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:27.270
created by, this is just one page worth.

39
00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:31.800
So, if I scroll over here, there's also

40
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:38.000
I know what way over here, let's probably
do the plug in this to my cable here but

41
00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:42.580
if I click the arrow there and
this is properties 51 to 100.

42
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:48.670
So there are literally hundreds of
properties that can be crawled,

43
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:55.030
detected language for example, document
signature, let's look at one more screen.

44
00:02:55.030 --> 00:02:58.760
We're not gonna cover absolutely
everything, all the properties, but

00:19:05.330 --> 00:19:07.710

00:19:19.230 --> 00:19:24.420

00:19:24.420 --> 00:19:28.000

00:19:31.530 --> 00:19:34.455

our task becomes as search administrators,

00:20:33.798 --> 00:20:35.300

00:21:07.870 --> 00:21:11.940

00:21:50.290 --> 00:21:57.350

00:23:33.700 --> 00:23:36.740

prem you might be familiar with,

a significant amount of time.

00:24:19.660 --> 00:24:24.191

the correct permissions to access

00:24:24.191 --> 00:24:26.698

episodes.description: In this episode, Mark and Mike take a look at integrating SharePoint Online with other online technologies. They start with OneDrive and Yammer, exploring different options available. Then they look at Delve, Sway and the Office Store.
